Water holes, dams and rivers become a hive of activity and you are more likely to spot wildlife in the morning and evening as animals come to drink. The day temperatures in winter are pleasant but it can get quite chilly during the night-time so make sure you pack something warm when going on your afternoon/night game drives.

This tour only visits Kruger National Park but we stay in three very different sections. We will travel in and out of the nearest airport town of Nelspruit.

Recommended Fitness Level:

The vast majority of wildlife watching is all done from the 4x4 safari vehicle so any fitness level can participate. Where guided walks are offered they will be taken at a slow pace and last no longer than an hour or so.

Minimum Age: 18 years old

dayInfo.description: Nelspruit / Kruger National Park – Arrival – On arrival at the airport in Nelspruit you will be met by your local guide (who will act as your driver as well) and depending on the time you arrived we will either head straight towards the main gate into Kruger National Park and onto a first camp (1-2 hours), in the south of the park. If this is the case then we will get your first opportunity to view Kruger National Parks wildlife as we drive through the south of the park towards our camp but if your flight is an afternoon arrival you will be transferred to a guesthouse in Nelspruit. The rest of the evening is at your leisure. (No meals included today).

Kruger National Park / Nelspruit ¬– Travelling & Wildlife Watching – Today we will rise more leisurely and have breakfast before heading out into the park. We will then be on the road south-west as we head out of the park towards Nelspurit. This will take most of the day as we will be game driving. We will stop for lunch along the way at another camp. We will have your farewell evening meal at the guesthouse in Nelspruit as we go over the wonderful sights we have seen and experienced throughout the safari of Kruger National Park. (Breakfast and a packed lunch included).
Home – Departure – This morning you will be transferred to the airport in time to catch the return flight to home. (Breakfast only).

tourName: Kruger, Swaziland and South Africa's Ggrden route holiday
generalInfo:
Travel through the heart of South Africa in search of the Big 5. On this 21-day trip, we'll delve into some of the country's most iconic national parks, including Kruger, hoping to spot the bounty of wildlife that calls these varied landscapes home. Along the way, immerse yourself in the history of the Zulu battlefield, explore the wetlands of St Lucia and rub shoulders with the Swazi people in Eswatini.

Kruger National Park - Get the chance to spot the Big 5 on a game drive in Kruger - one of Africa's biggest game reserves.

Hluhluwe iMfolozi - Explore the game reserve which has the biggest rhino population in Africa.

Mlilwane - Get closer to South Africa's wildlife on an intimate walking safari in this secluded sanctuary beneath the Nyonyane Mountains.

dayInfo.title: Join trip Johannesburg Airport; drive to the Drakensberg Mountains
dayInfo.description: : Our tour starts today in Johannesburg, South Africa's largest city, once home to both Nelson Mandela and Desmond Tutu. Your tour leader will meet you at 10.30am at O.R. Tambo International Airport (JNB) and we aim to depart no later than 11.30am. From the airport, we'll drive southeast to the Drakensberg Mountains (a journey of around four-and-a-half hours). Drakensberg is the world's oldest mountain range, deriving its name from the Afrikaans word for 'Dragon Mountains'; in the mist, the razor-back ridges of the mountains have a likeness to these mythical beasts. Upon arrival to our accommodation, there might be time to take a short walk in the surrounding nature. If you're booking your own flights to Johannesburg, we recommend giving yourself plenty of time to clear the airport. The latest your flight can arrive is 10.30am.

dayInfo.title: Walk in Drakensberg World Heritage Site
dayInfo.description: : This morning, after a hearty breakfast, we'll have the opportunity to join a guided walk and experience the beauty of the mountain range first-hand. The full walk takes around four to five hours and we've graded it as moderate-to-challenging. There are several turning points along the way for those who'd like to do a more gentle walk. Weather permitting, upon returning to our hotel, our guide will have prepared a tasty 'al fresco' lunch for us to enjoy while we soak up the spectacular views of the Drakensberg. The afternoon is left free to either relax whilst enjoying a cool drink or perhaps continue our adventure with an easy walk through the mountain valleys to view a rock carving close to camp.

dayInfo.title: Visit battlefields; drive on to St Lucia
dayInfo.description: : We'll set off early this morning and head to the famous battlefield of Rorke's Drift, arriving around mid-morning. Portrayed in the 1964 movie Zulu , the battle at Rorke's Drift was a bloody and hugely significant battle in the history of the Zulu nation, depicting the 1879 battle between the local Zulu and the British Army. Although time is limited today, due to the distance we have to travel, our tour leader will take time to explain the importance of these clashes in relation to South Africa's history, British colonialism and the Zulu people. After a lunch stop, we'll drive for the rest of the afternoon to St Lucia, our base for the next three nights.

dayInfo.title: Game Drives in Hluhluwe-iMfolozi Game Reserve
dayInfo.description: : We'll have another early start this morning to take advantage of the 'golden hour' on a Big 5 safari in one of Africa's oldest game reserves. Hluhluwe-iMfolozi Park boasts the densest population of both white and black rhinos in the whole of Africa. We'll have our breakfast at one of the reserve's picnic sites, where we can stretch our legs and freshen up before continuing our safari journey. With over 500 species of birds recorded at this reserve, it's also a paradise for any birdwatchers amongst us. In the afternoon, we'll return to St. Lucia where we'll have the opportunity to experience the optional activity of a 'Hippo Cruise' on the Greater St. Lucia Estuary. The cruise meanders along allowing us to relax whilst viewing the hippos and crocodiles in their natural habitat as the sun drops from the African sky. Other activities includes a bicycle tour, a turtle safari (in season only) and an evening game drive in Isimangaliso Wetland reserve.

dayInfo.title: At St Lucia Wetland Reserve
dayInfo.description: : Today you're free to choose from one of several optional activities. There is the opportunity to continue our game-viewing experience by taking a leisurely open game drive in the iSimangaliso Wetland Park, which was the first World Heritage Site in South Africa and home to four of the Big 5. The word iSimangaliso means miracle and wonder, which aptly describes this truly unique place. This optional activity also includes a typical 'braai' lunch at Cape Vidal. There is also the chance explore the local forest hiking trails. In the evening, you can enjoy an exhilarating night game drive when all the nocturnal wildlife start their day. From November to February, we can join a guided turtle tour in the Wetland.

dayInfo.title: Drive to Eswatini
dayInfo.description: : This morning, we'll make our way to Eswatini, from June to November we may have the opportunity to participate in the optional activity of whale watching, the St. Lucia coastline is the optimal location to view Humpback whales as they make their way up the coastline to Mozambique to breed. We'll then drive north and enter Eswatini - a tiny, independent kingdom inhabited by the Swazi tribe who revere their king and take great pride in retaining their culture and traditions. Along the way, we can soak up the spectacular scenery of the Ezulwini Valley, dotted with traditional homesteads. Once we have arrived safely in the Kingdom of Eswatini we will make our first rest stop at the artisan craft market at Swazi Candles near Malkerns. Famous across the world for their colorful and beautiful wax candle designs a visit here is a great way to interact with the local artisinal craftsmen and to witness first hand how so simple as a wax candle can support a whole community. In the late afternoon, we'll enter one of Eswatini's best wildlife reserves, Mlilwane Wildlife Sanctuary. This secluded and beautiful sanctuary is a haven of tranquillity, located in a natural bowl beneath the Nyonyane Mountains. For the next two nights, we'll stay in traditional dome-shaped beehive huts set in a wooded area. Though the camp has all the mod cons - showers, toilets, outdoor swimming pool and restaurant and bar - it is rustic in the best sense of the word. Warthogs, nyala and antelope share the camp with us, and the restaurant overlooks a lake populated by water birds, crocodiles and terapins. Due to the high demand in Mlilwane, accommodation is subject to change without notice and can vary in style. We'll endeavour to stay within the park when possible, however, some departures may be staying up to a 15-minute drive from the sanctuary in a hotel or guesthouse.

dayInfo.title: Game viewing and optional activities in Mlilwane Wildlife Sanctuary
dayInfo.description: : Mlilwane is Eswatini's oldest protected area, owned and managed by a non-profit making trust, it is situated in the low foothills of the Nyonyane Mountains. The park has been rehabilitated to become Eswatini's most frequented reserve where you can enjoy the beauty of the surroundings and the abundant wildlife that calls these plains home. Mlilwane has a large area of open grassland making game viewing and bird watching relatively easy and this morning we'll begin with a walk in search of zebra, wildebeest, nyala and warthog. The afternoon is free to choose one of the optional activities available at the reserve, the absence of big cats allows us to partake in mountain biking or trail walking in a relaxed setting. The alternatives are to accompany our guide to the local village of Mantenga, a living-museum to learn more about the Swazi people, their traditions and their culture, or you could simple relax and sit back to watch the local wildlife grazing outside our very own front door.

dayInfo.title: Drive to Kruger National Park
dayInfo.description: : After an early start, we'll drive north re-entering South Africa and crossing the Crocodile River into the Kruger National Park. This two-million-hectare wilderness is amongst the world's first proclaimed National Park and is justifiably South Africa's showpiece, boasting over 145 mammal species. The park offers the Big 5 and over 500 recorded bird species along with scenery as diverse as riverine forest, granite outcrops, endless savannah and impenetrable mopani woodland. We'll take a game drive on our way to the accommodation where we'll stay overnight. We will be staying just outside the park gates at a newly designed modernistic property offering a fantastic location with all the amenities required and will be enjoying a typical african braai on the patio before getting an early night.

dayInfo.title: Game viewing in Kruger National Park; drive to Graskop
dayInfo.description: : The Kruger National Park was established in 1898 to protect big game that had been hunted to near extinction. Today it is one of South Africa's most prolific wildlife habitats and a leader in animal conservation. We'll set out very early for a full day in the park, beginning with game viewing at various watering holes where we might see buffalo or antelope taking an early morning drink and, with luck, a pride of lions nearby. Midday we'll pause for lunch at one of the park's restaurants before continuing our safari in the afternoon, heading towards the Sabie River. This is a major water source for the park's wildlife and an excellent spot for game viewing. After a rewarding day exploring Kruger, we'll leave the park mid-afternoon and climb more than 1,000 metres to our overnight stop at Graskop. Please note, not all members of the group will fly to Cape Town tomorrow, and you may have a new tour leader for the second half of the trip.

dayInfo.title: Drive to O.R. Tambo International Airport (JNB) and fly to Cape Town
dayInfo.description: : Departing at 7am this morning we drive for around 7 hours back to Johannesburg. Along the way, we'll drive through the airy uplands of Mpumalanga, an area that has been inhabited since the Stone Age and boasts rivers, multiple waterfalls, craggy escarpments and colourful birdlife. We'll stop at several excellent viewpoints, including the aptly named 'God's Window' and admire the awe-inspiring Blyde River Canyon. We'll arrive into O.R. Tambo International Airport (JNB) at about 5pm and from here you'll fly to Cape Town. You will arrive in Cape Town, South Africa's Mother City, in the early evening. Upon landing in Cape Town Airport please proceed to the Visitor Information Centre in the Central Terminal near the exit marked by a big 'i' symbol, where your driver will be waiting for you with a sign. The transfer from Cape Town International Airport to our hotel is around 40 minutes. Please note, due to different arrival times throughout the evening, the welcome meeting with your tour leader will take place on the morning of Day 11, after breakfast.

dayInfo.title: Explore Cape Peninsula National Park
dayInfo.description: : Our full-day trip to Cape Peninsula begins with a scenic drive via the white-sand beaches of Fish Hoek, stopping to explore the small but important naval base of Simon's Town. Later, we'll arrive at Cape of Good Hope, allegedly named due to the optimism once felt by arriving colonial sailors having successfully navigated the Cape and discovering a sea route to the East. We'll take an hour-long walk within the national park to Cape Point and the lighthouse, keeping an eye out for resident baboons, tortoises, otters, and seabirds along the way. The trail is well marked, slightly rocky in places, and boasts diverse flora with many colourful flowers. We'll return to Cape Town via Hout Bay, an attractive fishing port once bordered by dense forest, hence its name, which translates as 'Wood Bay'. Here, we'll have the option of taking a short boat trip out to Seal Island - home to 1,000 Cape fur seals and guarded by the impressive, towering Sentinel Mountain. Alternatively, explore on dry land to see Hout Bay's active tuna, snoek and crayfish industry and find out why the town prides itself on offering some of the best fish and chips in the world.

dayInfo.title: Free day in Cape Town; evening in Stellenbosch
dayInfo.description: : This morning is free for you to explore Cape Town more at your own pace, and there are plenty of options for you to pick from. If you want to visit Robben Island, the former prison where Nelson Mandela was incarcerated, this morning is the best time to go. Please note, you'll need to book in advance (please see the optional activities section of visit www.robben-island.org.za). There are three departures per day, and the 9am departure is the best option to fit with our itinerary. Alternatively, the morning is also the best time to hike up Table Mountain. The favourable morning weather and temperatures make it a more enjoyable experience and you'll get breathtaking views over the Apostles, the Atlantic and the city below. The walk up to the viewpoint takes between three to four hours. There is also the option to take the aerial cable car to the top, which runs frequently to and from the summit, where a network of trails criss-crosses the plateau and provides a variety of vantage points. While it's possible to visit Robben Island and take the cable car to Table Mountain in the same day, you won't have time to visit Robben Island and hike up Table Mountain. If you'd like to do both, you can book a pre-trip stay to give yourself more time. Please also note that both of these activities are weather-dependent and windy weather may change things. Another option is to take a trip to the Kirstenbosch National Botanical Gardens, which claims to be the most beautiful garden in Africa and is devoted to the conservation of the Cape's indigenous species. Your Tour Leader will be able to give further local advice and recommendations on how to spend your time in Cape Town. Late this afternoon, we'll leave Cape Town and head to the scenic winelands of Stellenbosch where you can relax with a local Chenin Blanc Please note, both Robben Island and Table Mountain are weather-dependent. Table Mountain's cableway is closed for two weeks at the end of July for maintenance.

dayInfo.title: Free day in Stellenbosch to visit a vineyard
dayInfo.description: : There are no set plans for this morning, so you are free to explore Stellenbosch at your leisure. Consider visiting the University Botanical Gardens to learn about native plants, going curio shopping, or browsing the various galleries scattered throughout the town. Stellenbosch is world-famous for its wine, and there's no better way to experience this than by visiting one of the many vineyards in the area, which is exactly what we will do in the afternoon. Depending on the season, your Tour Leader will select a suitable vineyard where we can sample several local wines while immersing ourselves in the unique South African wine culture. Many of the estates feature spectacular gardens and farmland, providing opportunities for lunch and a leisurely stroll. There is also the option to take a guided tour of Stellenbosch Town, a great way to learn about the diverse cultures that have contributed to making Stellenbosch what it is today. As one of the oldest colonial settlements, this charming town boasts wide, oak-lined streets and beautiful whitewashed Cape Dutch architecture. You'll find many cafes, bars, and delis for lunch, most of which pride themselves on using local produce.

dayInfo.title: Travel to Hermanus via Stony Point's African Penguin Colony
dayInfo.description: : This morning we make our way down to Hermanus, on the coast. A 90-minute drive takes us to the Betty's Bay area where we'll have an included visit to Stony Point Nature Reserve. This reserve sits on the site of a historic whaling station and has a quiet, undiscovered feel, offering excellent penguin viewing without the crowds. The path can be followed over the craggy outcrops to see the resident seabirds up close without disturbing them. We then continue to our accommodation in central Hermanus. This afternoon is free to explore the coastal town. From June to November, Hermanus offers some of the world's best shore-based whale watching, with good opportunities to spot southern right, Bryde's and humpback whales. Although there is a good chance of seeing the whales from the water's edge in town, you may prefer to follow the coastal path to a better vantage point or join a boat trip excursion for a closer view. At other times of the year, you might like to spend the day exploring the galleries and museums in Hermanus, which are easy to discover on foot, or enjoying the coastal views from the 8km walking path that runs right along the cliff edge. This evening will be at your leisure, with a variety of excellent restaurants and wine bars to discover.

dayInfo.title: Visit Cape Agulhas. Spend the night in Barrydale
dayInfo.description: : A 90-minute drive takes us to the southernmost point of the African continent this morning, where we see the Atlantic Ocean and the Indian Ocean meeting in a crash of waves. Now marked by a stone plaque, the 'Cape of Needles' was once the site of various shipwrecks and a grave point of danger for European travellers. We'll have a little free time to explore the magnificent monument. This afternoon, we continue towards Barrydale on the renowned Route 62 (one of the longest wine routes in the world). The Tradouw Pass (which means Women's Pass in the old Khoi language) is a 16 kilometre/10 mile-long drive, offering some of the most beautiful and rugged scenery in this region of South Africa. Barrydale is a scenic little place with the air of a Wild West frontier town about it. We'll stop here to break up our long drive to Oudtshoorn. If you have any time this evening or tomorrow morning, a walk around the backstreets reveals a couple of small art shops and some beautiful scenery. We have an included dinner tonight - local restaurants here have a big lunch trade but close around 5pm, so we'll enjoy some local food at our small hotel. The total drive time today from Hermanus is approximately five hours.

dayInfo.title: Explore Swellendam, continue to Oudtshoorn in the Klein Karoo, the ostrich capital of the world.
dayInfo.description: : After a late start in Barrydale, we continue our journey for around two hours to Oudtshoorn, driving past open farmland and winelands. This seemingly empty plain is in fact home to vast numbers of ostrich, and we'll likely spot them in the farms that run alongside Route 62 as we drive. Oudtshoorn is the principal town in the Klein Karoo, which grew in the early 1900s thanks to its rich trade in ostrich feathers. We may have time to have a quick explore of the shops and the small curio museum before driving onto the huge limestone caverns of the Cango Caves. These caves are an underground network of extraordinary structures, millions of years old. The combination of dripping rainwater and limestone has led to the creation of ancient stalactites, stalagmites, and mighty rock columns. Allegedly, a local European farmer first discovered the caves late in the 18th century; however, there is research that proves the caves have been used by man as far back as the early Stone Age. After a visit to the caves, we drive on to our countryside lodgings for the evening.

dayInfo.title: Visit Cango Caves and take in the views at Knysna Heads
dayInfo.description: : Today we make our way back down to the coast and the start of the Garden Route proper, driving south through the town of George towards the ocean. At the small town of Sedgefield we'll stop at Swartvlei Beach where we'll have about an hour's walk along the wild and scenic coast with a guide from the Strandloper Project. This small project began in 2018 when a group of locals decided to organise a reef clean up to tackle the threats posed to the reef and native marine wildlife, from discarded fishing tackle. The project has expanded onto the land, and the volunteers now use microplastic collection data from the beach to lobby regional councils about their plastic waste. The walk on the beach is spectacular, and we'll learn not just about the project but also about the surrounding environment. After our visit here we continue our drive to Knysna Heads Viewpoint, where two limestone cliffs emerge from the Indian Ocean, side by side, protecting a lagoon that runs inland from the turbulent sea. We'll end the day in Plettenberg Bay, on the Indian Ocean. Today's total drive time is approximately three hours.

dayInfo.title: Discover Robberg Nature Reserve. Free afternoon in Plettenberg Bay
dayInfo.description: : Today we take a short drive to Robberg Nature Reserve, a World Heritage Site, where our Tour Leader will lead a walk along the trails. The hiking here is moderately graded, and good stability and fitness are both essential. Rewards for tackling the rocky terrain, sand dunes and occasional steep steps are great - sweeping coastal views, beautiful golden sands, and the possibility to spot dolphins and seals playing in the waters below. From July to December there's also the chance to spot the southern right whales that come into the calmer and warmer waters to calve and nurse their young. For those who don't want to undertake the 5.5km loop with the Tour Leader, there is a shorter 2km loop, or you could simply enjoy the fantastic views from the clifftops. After working up an appetite, we'll stop for a well-deserved lunch in Plettenberg Bay. Seafood is a favourite on the menu here - hake, meaty prawns or calamari washed down with a crisp white wine. Afterwards, the afternoon is free with the option to relax on the beach, shop for souvenirs or join a whale-watching excursion (in season).

dayInfo.title: Walk, kayak or discover the tree canopy at Tsitsikamma National Park
dayInfo.description: : The wild coast of Tsitsikamma National Park awaits today, around a 45-minute drive away. Another hotspot for seasonal whale watching, the national park covers both land and sea, protecting important forest and marine areas, and offering stunning coastal views. We'll be staying in the Storms River region. Timings today may vary depending on a number of factors, but there is the opportunity here to take a short but steeply-stepped walk to a series of three suspension bridges that overlook the mouth of Storms River as it reaches the sea. You may also like to try your hand at zip wiring (a short drive out of the national park), or an adventurous river kayaking trip up the Storms River (this involves a walk of approximately 20 minutes carrying your paddle, jacket and helmet - it's a stunning river paddle but not a leisurely activity!) Tonight we'll be staying in simply furnished chalets set either amongst the forest, or on the clifftop.

dayInfo.title: Experience a game drive at Addo Elephant National Park
dayInfo.description: : We'll leave the Tsitsikamma area this morning for another of South Africa's national parks. It's a long drive of approximately three hours plus stops. Home to more than 600 elephants as well as lions, hyenas and Cape buffalos, Addo Elephant National Park is our last national park of the trip. On arrival, we'll swap into one of the park's safari trucks - perfect for the terrain and for capturing great wildlife shots - for a two-hour game drive with a park guide. Warthogs are abundant here, along with various species of antelope, zebra and of course elephant. After our game drive, we'll make our way to our accommodation, which is located 20 minutes outside Addo Elephant National Park. Often our hosts here at the small, family-run property will treat us to a proper South African braai this evening, a fitting end to your Garden Route journey

dayInfo.title: Trip ends at Addo Elephant Park
dayInfo.description: : Our trip ends after breakfast at our accommodation near Addo Elephant National Park. There are no activities planned today, so you're free to depart from Addo at any time. Check-out from our accommodation is at 10am. If you'd like a transfer today, you'll need to depart from Port Elizabeth International Airport (PLZ), which is a one-hour drive from Addo.

tourName: Kwa Zulu Natal and beach, self drive
generalInfo:
Begin a captivating 12-day adventure in the heart of South Africa, where a rich tapestry of experiences awaits you. From the moment you touch down at King Shaka Airport, your journey unfolds seamlessly, offering a delightful fusion of opulence, cultural exploration, and awe-inspiring natural beauty. Explore the timeless allure of your lodgings, savor a wide array of culinary delights, and embark on an exciting exploration of South Africa's diverse landscapes, its historical significance, and its vibrant wildlife.

As your adventure progresses, fully immerse yourself in the grandeur of mountains, delve into historic battlefields, conquer thrilling white-water rapids, and behold the untamed wilderness of game reserves.

Your expedition reaches its zenith in a coastal paradise, where pristine beaches and underwater marvels are sure to create enduring memories of your South African journey.

dayInfo.description: Arrive at King Shaka Airport and commence an exciting adventure. Following the pickup of your rental car, you'll enjoy a swift 30-minute drive to The Grange Guesthouse in Umhlanga. This delightful estate, a relic of the 1950s, features lofty ceilings and rich wooden flooring, radiating an enduring sense of grace. Your deluxe king room affords picturesque ocean views and contemporary conveniences, promising a cozy and luxurious stay. As the sun dips below the horizon, savor the delectable offerings of Mo Noodles, an Asian fusion paradise.

Your adventure continues with an unforgettable three-day stay at Three Tree Hill Lodge, nestled against the majestic Drakensberg Mountains. Following a satisfying breakfast at The Grange Guesthouse, you'll embark on a picturesque journey to Bergville, your destination for the day. Along the way, you'll discover the enchanting Midlands Meander, renowned as the 'arts and crafts route.' With over 160 establishments offering dining, shopping, and cultural exploration, this route guides you through a diverse and captivating blend of arts, crafts, and local traditions. Your lunch will be a culinary delight at Eaves Restaurant in Granny Mouse. As the day draws to a close, you'll reach Three Tree Hill Lodge, where a 3-course plated dinner and your cozy double cottage eagerly await. Day 3 begins with a buffet-style breakfast at Three Tree Hill Lodge, setting the stage for an action-packed day. You'll have the opportunity to engage in a range of activities, from scenic mountain biking to thrilling trail rides on the working cattle farm, with occasional wildlife sightings. For those seeking a more adventurous experience, bushwalks in the neighboring Spioenkop Game Reserve can be arranged, guiding you through rugged, hilly terrain for an immersive nature encounter. Lunch is served at the lodge, and another delightful dinner marks the end of the day's adventures. On Day 4, your morning commences with breakfast at Three Tree Hill, providing you with the energy needed for a self-guided hike to the awe-inspiring Tugela Falls. Following this adventure, lunch awaits at the lodge, and the afternoon offers you the freedom to relax or explore at your own pace. Dinner back at Three Tree Hill promises to be a delightful affair.

Leaving Three Tree Hill after breakfast, you'll set off on your voyage to Vryheid, traversing the historic Battlefields Region. Here, the echoes of bygone conflicts add a profound layer of meaning to your journey. A break for lunch at The Shed in Dundee will introduce you to the delightful local cuisine. Your canoeing expedition on the Bivane River promises an exciting rendezvous with white-water excitement. As the day draws to a close, you'll relish a dinner infused with regional flavors at Koubad Farm Lodge, your lodging for the night.

Days 6 to 8 will immerse you in the heart of Zululand, commencing with a delightful breakfast at Koubad Farm. Your journey will take you to Hluhluwe, where history converges with conservation. This village was once the residence of Zulu kings Dingiswayo and Shaka, who played pivotal roles in establishing South Africa's oldest game reserve in 1895 - the Hluhluwe iMfolozi Game Reserve. After a picturesque 3-hour and 30-minute drive from Vryheid, you'll arrive at Rhino Ridge Safari Lodge, a veritable oasis in this unspoiled wilderness. Savor lunch at the lodge, setting the stage for an afternoon game drive. Keep a vigilant eye out for the "Big 5" - Black and White Rhinoceros, Elephant, Buffalo, Lion, and Leopard, among other mesmerizing wildlife. Evenings at Rhino Ridge are graced with exquisite dinners and accommodations in lavish Bush Villas. These expansive abodes seamlessly blend luxury with nature, boasting open-plan layouts, cozy lounges, inviting fireplaces, and sweeping viewing decks. The oversized bathrooms offer rain showers and sumptuous bathtubs with panoramic vistas of the African bush. Days 7 and 8 promise double doses of safari thrills, with morning game drives that reveal the crimson dawn and the iconic African fauna. Your knowledgeable guide will not only introduce you to the "Big 5" but also provide insights into the park's ecosystems and its diverse wildlife.

The adventure unfolds over the next three days at Thonga Beach Lodge, a captivating sanctuary nestled within the pristine iSimangaliso Wetland Park, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. After one final exhilarating morning game drive and a hearty breakfast at Rhino Lodge, prepare for a picturesque drive towards your haven at Thonga Beach Lodge. This exceptional destination can only be accessed via an exhilarating 4x4 transfer from the designated pickup point in Sodwana Bay, where your vehicle will be securely parked. Upon arrival at Thonga Beach Lodge, you'll be greeted by the lap of luxury as you settle into your Deluxe Ocean View Room. These accommodations provide sweeping views of the Indian Ocean, each complete with a private plunge pool and an expansive deck. Throughout your stay, relish in delectable breakfasts, leisurely lunches, and romantic dinners, all against the backdrop of the awe-inspiring ocean. Days 10 and 11 usher in a coastal paradise where you can revel in the splendor of unspoiled, untamed beaches. Don't miss the opportunity for scuba diving at Thonga Beach, where vibrant reefs, just a short distance from the lodge, promise mesmerizing encounters with schools of game fish, awe-inspiring sharks, and the playful antics of bottlenose dolphins in the crystal-clear waters. You can also take your time to unwind on the beach or sway gently in hammocks, surrendering to the soothing melodies of the ocean. For those seeking more relaxation, indulge in well-deserved pampering at the resort's spa, where a diverse array of rejuvenating and beauty treatments awaits your selection. And for those craving adventure, embark on kayaking expeditions on Lake Sibaya, offering the chance to catch glimpses of hippos and crocodiles in their natural habitat. Alternatively, immerse yourself in the enchanting world of the forest with captivating nature walks and birdwatching experiences that promise to leave you utterly captivated.

Delight in your final breakfast at Thonga Beach Lodge before embarking on your journey to King Shaka Airport. The picturesque 5-hour, 350-kilometer drive will return you to the airport, where you'll return your rental car before stepping onto your flight home, carrying with you indelible memories from this extraordinary South African escapade. Wishing you a safe journey!

tourName: Kwa Zulu Natal family adventure holiday
generalInfo:
Ideal for families with teenagers, this adventurous holiday has plenty to keep everyone occupied.
Start off at a lodge in the UNESCO World Heritage Drakensberg Mountains, for outdoor activities in stunning surroundings: hike to waterfalls, take a picnic on a mountain bike trail, zip line through the forest, or go horse riding.

Move on to a lovely family-run lodge for rhino tracking on foot, nature trails, scoo-tours, battlefield tours and sundowners in stunning settings. This is a very special place to be.

Then spend 3 nights on safari at an owner-run lodge on a private concession. This is Big 5 territory, so game drives will provide the thrill of potentially seeing lion, elephant, rhino, buffalo and leopard - learn about the bush with your trained guide on day and evening safaris. As well as game drives, the lodge offers the opportunity to become involved in conservation experience, including Priority Species Tracking and Rhino Horn Trimming. (Subject to availability).

End your trip at a remote beach lodge: activities include kayaking, beach fat-biking, snorkelling - and at certain times of year, you may see turtles hatching and whales breaching off the coast. The food at all lodges is superb - here the focus is on seafood - and the hospitality at a level you might expect from small, owner managed and run lodges.

dayInfo.description: Spend 3 nights at a remote beach lodge, tucked away on the furthest coast of Kwazulu-Natal, in iSimangaliso Nature Reserve. Getting there is not for the faint hearted, but it's all part of the adventure:, as it includes a 1-hour jeep transfer along sandy tracks to the lodge, which is set deep in dune forests above the endless sands of the beach. There are two pools, a dive centre, a blissful spa, and a superb al fresco restaurant and bar. Activities include spectacular snorkelling in the 'home reef' a short walk away, with prolific angelfish as well as turtles, shrimps, anemones and tiger cowries; kayaking (including guided kayaking excursions on Lake Sibaya), guided walks through the forest and turtle tours, with turtles laying their eggs on the beach and hatching between November and March, beach volleyball, cricket - and of course, relaxation.
Return your hire vehicle to Durban airport: you may opt to overnight on the coast before your return flight.

tourName: Kwa Zulu Natal safari, off the beaten track
generalInfo:
Ideal for second time visitors to South Africa, or anyone looking to get off the beaten track, this adventurous holiday has lots of variety to offer.

Start off at a lodge in the UNESCO World Heritage Drakensberg Mountains, for outdoor activities in stunning surroundings: hike to waterfalls, take a picnic on a mountain bike trail, visit an authentic Zulu village, or go horse riding.

Move on to a lovely family-run lodge for nature trails, scoo-tours, battlefield tours and sundowners in stunning settings. This is a very special place to be.

Then spend 3 nights on safari at an owner-run lodge on a private concession. This is Big 5 territory, so game drives will provide the thrill of potentially seeing lion, elephant, rhino, buffalo and leopard - learn about the bush with your trained guide on day and evening safaris. As well as game drives, the lodge offers the opportunity to become involved in conservation experience, including Priority Species Tracking and Rhino Horn Trimming. (Subject to availability).

End your trip at a remote beach lodge: activities include kayaking, beach fat-biking, snorkelling - and at certain times of year, you may see turtles hatching and whales breaching off the coast. The food at all lodges is superb - here the focus is on seafood - and the hospitality at a level you might expect from small, owner managed and run lodges.

dayInfo.description: Return your hire vehicle to Durban airport: you may opt to overnight on the coast before your return flight.

tourName: Kwa Zulu Natal self drive holiday
placesVisited: Ukhahlamba Drakensberg National Park, Tugela Gorge & Waterfall, KwaZulu-Natal Battlefields, St Lucia oceanside village, Wildlife drives in private reserves, Optional activities include: snorkelling, kayaking, fishing, quad biking, stargazing, hiking and horse riding, Trip extensions are also available
generalInfo:
This fabulously flexible fortnight in the KwaZulu-Natal region of South Africa invites travellers to experience a self drive itinerary that features UNESCO sites, historic battlegrounds and some of South Africa’s lesser-visited private wildlife reserves and Indian Ocean beaches.

From two nights in the Drakensberg Mountains to three nights on the KwaZulu-Natal coast in St Lucia, although this is a driving holiday you’ll still be offered ample excuses to relax and take it all in. Of course, as this is a tailor made tour you’re free to choose how much or how little free time you wish to add to the suggested itinerary below. KwaZulu-Natal is an extraordinary region and abundant in tribal heritage and opportunities to watch wildlife in their natural habitat.

Exploring on two feet or two wheels is a great way to stretch your legs outside of your hire car with hiking and mountain biking in the Drakensberg just as immersive as snorkelling or deep sea fishing in the Indian Ocean.

The added incentive for families is that the KwaZulu-Natal region is malaria-free as well as allowing kids, and parents, to explore a less-visited province of South Africa away from the crowds along the coast.

Pick your points of interest and design a self drive holiday to suit you as this is an area of Africa that really does require closer inspection from a wide range of perspectives.

dayInfo.description: Arrive Durban, collect your hire car and drive to your accommodation for 2 nights at a wonderful lodge in the southern Drakensberg Mountains. The Drakensberg Mountains (a UNESCO World Heritage site), South Africa’s highest and most dramatic range, offer staggering scenery of basalt cliffs, grasslands, forests, and crystal-clear streams. The region is a paradise for outdoor enthusiasts—hiking trails lead to waterfalls, wildlife, and ancient San rock art sites that reveal the cultural history of the area. This itinerary uses an owner-run lodge that is situated in a truly romantic setting surrounded by mountains, creating a magical atmosphere. They look forward to welcoming guests with gourmet food, roaring log fires and luxurious farmhouse hospitality. Their emphasis on providing gastronomic standard cuisine is demonstrated in the hours they spend hunting down the highest quality ingredients. Dinner is a sumptuous 5-course affair with no effort or expense spared to give guests a memorable dining experience. A host talks you through every mouthful from pan to plate before you sit down to enjoy the culinary team's creations. Fresh ingredients are essential, and being able to pick from the gardens minutes before serving is a real pleasure. To work up an appetite, take a scenic drive in an open game viewer to explore the magnificent view from on top of the mountain, while horse rides are available for the more energetic. In the locality, explore the Rock Art at Kamberg, or superb hiking can be done on the Reserve.

It's a scenic drive today to the Northern Drakensberg Mountains, for a 2 night stay at a peaceful and luxurious lodge in one of South Africa’s most scenic regions. This family-run lodge is known for its warm hospitality, spacious suites, and sweeping mountain views—best enjoyed from your private patio. Days here can be as relaxing or adventurous as you choose. Explore a network of private hiking, biking, and horse-riding trails that wind through pristine grasslands and dramatic sandstone formations. Or simply unwind by the pool, enjoy a soothing massage, and soak in the tranquility of the surrounding landscapes. With delicious home-style meals served in a cosy dining room overlooking the mountains, the lodge combines comfort, natural beauty, and heartfelt charm.

Surely a highlight of this trip: a 2 night safari on a private concession. Nestled in the heart of KwaZulu-Natal’s wildlife-rich Lowveld, the Safari Lodge offers an intimate and authentic safari experience, combining comfort with close encounters with Africa’s iconic wildlife. The lodge sits on a private concession bordering the world-renowned Hluhluwe-iMfolozi Park, giving guests exclusive access to pristine bushveld and abundant wildlife. Days are filled with morning and afternoon game drives, led by expert guides whose tracking skills, wildlife knowledge, and storytelling bring the African bush vividly to life. Guests may encounter the Big Five—elephants, lions, leopards, rhinos, and buffalo—alongside giraffes, zebras, hippos, and a variety of antelope. For bird enthusiasts, hundreds of species can be spotted from the lodge or during drives. Evenings are magical, with night drives revealing nocturnal wildlife in their natural habitat, and nights spent under a canopy of stars, where the Milky Way stretches across the African sky. Luxury tents with private decks offer comfort and panoramic views, creating a perfect blend of adventure and relaxation.

You have the option of extending your trip to stay at a lovely beach lodge in northern KZN with activities that can include snorkelling, kayaking, fishing, quad biking, stargazing and walks. Diving is can also be conducted within a Reserve and World Heritage Site along unspoiled reefs and guests have the luxury of knowing that they alone have access to the sites along this stretch of the coastline.
Today you drop off your hire vehicle in time for your return flight to Johannesburg,

tourName: Kwa Zulu Natal self drive South Africa holiday
placesVisited: The Midlands, Drakensberg Mountains, Royal Natal National Park, The Battlefields of the Anglo Zulu Wars, Phinda Private Game Reserve, Game drives and Kwa Zulu Natal wildlife safari, Elephant Coast
generalInfo:
This Kwa Zulu Natal self drive holiday takes you through one of South Africa’s most fascinating regions, historically and culturally but also one of its most beautiful. With a combination of the Drakensberg Mountains and Elephant Coast, with its empty beaches and subtropical forests, you will have the most stunning journey.

Following our carefully crafted itinerary, but travelling independently in your own hire car, we will book all the accommodation you need to fit in with your schedule, staying at quality hotels and guesthouses with which we have years of experience. We can, of course, tweak the itinerary to suit your interests and time frame.

Kwa Zulu Natal is South Africa’s secret gem, with first timers often heading for The Garden Route. Which is stunning of course, however this holiday is perfect for those coming back to South Africa for a second time and wanting to explore a new region. Or for those who are first timers, but with more of a penchant for off the beaten path adventure.

The trip starts in The Midlands, the rolling hills at the base of the Drakensberg Mountains which are home to a fine array of artists, artisan producers and, of course, wineries. You will have plenty of opportunities to sample the fine local fare at your accommodation , Hartford House and later at Montusi Mountain Lodge, also nestled in the in the ‘Berg’. The Drakensberg Mountains, and foothills, are of course a great location for hitting the hiking trails.
Moving on to The Battlefields of the Anglo-Zulu Wars, you can take a memorable guided tour around this area where, in 1879, the British army invaded Zululand and found themselves face to face with thousands of Zulu warriors.

Your next stop is all about nature, however, although not without its battles, with South Africa’s wildlife having had a history of endangerment, and Phinda Private Game Reserve is one of many examples of organisations that have contributed massively towards wildlife conservation. Spend several days here, staying in a safari lodge, enjoying game drives and safaris under the guidance of an expert ranger.

From Phinda’s elephants to the Elephant Coast, where most people go in search of the Indian Ocean and idyllic beaches rather than elephants these days. And the beaches certainly are colossal, particularly at Thonga Beach Resort where you will stay for three nights revelling in coastal bliss but also taking in some of the marine wildlife wonders. These include the endangered leatherhead turtle which nest here between November and March. In general, however, the best time to visit Kwa Zulu Natal is between April and August.

dayInfo.description: Today you'll depart the UK for Durban via Johannesburg.

Once you arrive in Johannesburg, you'll be met off the aircraft by a representative who will escort you through immigration and customs. You'll then connect on to your onward flight to Durban. Once you arrive in Durban, collect your hire car for your drive out to The Midlands for your two night stay at Hartford House.
Today is a free day to explore the Midlands and try some of the local produce such as cheese and chocolate as well as observe some of the local artisans at work in their studios.

Today you will make your way north along the Drakensburg to The Royal Natal National Park for your two night stay at Montusi Mountain Lodge which is situated in the northern Drakensberg. The lodge has fantastic views of the Drakensberg mountains.

Spend the day discovering what the Drakensburg have to offer and follow one of the trails that offer something for everyone. Activities at the lodge include guided hikes and horse-riding. Or if you prefer you could try out some adrenaline activities at the nearby adventure centre. Travelling further into the mountains from Montusi you can even visit the Tugela Falls and hike up the famous Amphitheatre if you are an experienced hiker.

Leave the picturesque mountains and make your way to The Battlefields of the Anglo Zulu wars where you will stay for two nights at Fugitive's Drift Guesthouse learning about a period that is so important to the Zulu's as well as the history of this diverse country. The drive to the Battlefields will be just under four hours.

Today you start at Isandlwana and listen to the mesmerizing tale of the Zulu victory. This afternoon you will be taken to the famous Rorkes Drift, you will be taken on an inspiring tour of this famous battle ground and hear the true story behind the famous film 'Zulu'.

Drive through the heart of Kwazulu Natal to the Phinda Private Game Reserve to spend four nights in one of the lodges enjoying an African safari. The drive is approximately five hours and we recommend arriving at lunchtime in order to settle in to the lodge and head out on your first afternoon game drive.

After your last morning game drive, make your way up to the Elephant Coast to meet your 4X4 transfer to take you to Thonga Beach Resort for the last 3 nights of your trip. The Elephant Coast is renowned for hippos, crocodiles and turtles which are found in the Kwazulu Natal Wetlands.

There are quite a few activities on offer in this part of South Africa. On shore you have a lush, green canopy, home to myriad birds, antelopes and monkeys, which creeps up high sand dunes that then fall away to amazing beaches. As well as their beauty and solitude, these areas are great for diving with a wonderful variety of sea life, including the turtles which make annual pilgrimages to the region to nest.

After your 4X4 transfer back to your car, you will make your way to Richards Bay Airport and the drive will take approximately four and a half hours. Once you arrive at the airport, you'll return your vehicle and board your flights to Johannesburg and then onwards back to the UK.
Arrive back in the UK.

tourName: Kwa-Zulu Natal tailor made tour, South Africa
placesVisited: Drakensberg Mountains UNESCO World Heritage National Park, Royal Natal National Park, Mountain trails, gorges and prehistoric rock art, Zululand Battlefields area including Rorkes Drift and Isandlwana, Hluhluwe Imfolozi Game Reserve, St Lucia estuary - iSimangaliso Wetland Park World Heritage site
generalInfo:
South Africa's Kwa Zulu Natal region contains two World Heritage Sites, the fascinating Zulu Battlefields and beautiful coastline as well as some lesser known game reserves for safaris. The area is rich in culture, history and scenery, making an ideal destination to explore with a local guide.

Your exploration of the Drakensberg Mountains combines superb hiking in places like the Didima Valley with a chance to cool off in mountain pools and also discover some of the many sites featuring prehistoric San rock art. Moving on to the Battlefields area at the heart of Zululand, visit famous conflict sites at Isandlwana and Rorke's Drift with local guides who will add not only historical context but also insights into Zulu traditions and culture.

In the Hluhluwe Imfolozi Game Reserve, expert game trackers and botanists will bring you closer in every sense to the breathtaking wildlife of Africa's oldest game reserve – including the continent's largest concentration of White Rhino.

The St Lucia estuary and iSimangaliso Wetland Park provide a marvellous finale in the shape of World Heritage wonderland where indigenous forests merge into wetlands fringed by the Indian Ocean. Featuring five contrasting eco systems there's an abundance of contrasting wildlife, where you can spot whale and dolphin on an estuary cruise, then do a guided game walk to see hippos and crocodiles. Add exploration of the local sand dunes and visits to a Zulu village.

NOTE: The itinerary below is a sample: this is a privately guided trip, so we can amend to suit different durations and to reflect specific interests

dayInfo.description: Depart on your overnight flight to Johannesburg
Today you transfer to Richards Bay airport, where you catch a flight to Johannesburg and will connect with your flight to the UK.
Arrive UK

tourName: KwaZulu Natal discovery tour, South Africa
placesVisited: Durban, Midlands Meander, Royal Natal National Park, Montusi Mountain, Bushman Cave, historic Battlefields region, Rorke's Drift, Isibindi Eco-Reserve, Optional activities include: horse riding, birdwatching, mountain biking, and hot air ballooning
generalInfo:
The eastern province of South Africa is not known as the ‘garden province’ for nothing and if you’ve got plans to experience some of Africa’s most verdant hillsides and peaceful rural towns then this 12 day tailor made tour is exactly what you’re looking for.

From Durban to the Drakensberg, this journey of discovery into KwaZulu Natal conjures up a superb selection of natural and cultural highlights with three days spent exploring in South Africa’s tallest mountain range always eagerly anticipated by outdoor enthusiasts and wildlife watchers alike.

The possibilities for walking tours in the Drakensberg are infinite with opportunities to discover more about contemporary Zulu culture adding to a well-rounded experience prior to heading to the northeast of KwaZulu Natal in search of historic heritage of a different nature.

From the British and the Boer to the indigenous Zulu tribes, the Battlefields region of KwaZulu Natal presents an eye opening encounter with South Africa’s political heritage with names like Isandlwana, Rorke’s Drift, Spioenkop and Blood River bound to live long in the memory.

By visiting KwaZulu Natal you’ll not only be discovering the region’s wealth of natural and historic heritage but you’ll also be giving back to some of South Africa’s most impoverished communities.

This tailor made itinerary includes accommodation that has been hand-picked to place your hard earned holiday funds where they’re needed most and, in so doing, you’ll be contributing to the conservation of the environment and traditional communities for many more years to follow.

dayInfo.description: Depart from London for your flight to Durban via Johannesburg.

You'll be meet on arrival in Johannesburg and assisted with your connection to Durban. On arrival in Durban you collect you hire car and make your way to the Midlands, which will take around two hours. You'll be staying at Granny Mouse for the next three nights.

Granny Mouse is located on the 'Midlands Meander', a beautiful region of rolling hills, open green plains and indigenous forest, with an outdoor focus as well as superb food. By visiting the local farms and buying local produce, you will be supporting the local economy in this impoverished region whilst tasting some delicious food! There are a number of pleasant small towns and fruit farms to explore and activities include horseriding and golf. The region is also well known for its huge diversity of birdlife, making this a birdwatcher's paradise.

Spend the day exploring the area visiting the local artisans and sampling the local food. For the more active, the Midlands region is well known for its superb hiking possibilities, with many marked trails ranging from an hour long stroll to 10 mile all day walks. There are also mountain biking and quad biking routes as well as the Karkloof Canopy Tour, an exhilirating three hour zip wire ride through the magnificent Karkloof indigenous forest.

After a final breakfast at Granny Mouse, you set off for the mighty Drakensberg range this morning. Your destination is the remote and spectacularly positioned Montusi Mountain Lodge near Royal Natal National Park located in the northern section of the Drakensberg, which you will reach in around two and a half hours. You then have the rest of the day at leisure to explore the stunning surroundings. You'll spend the next three nights at Montusi Mountain Lodge which enjoys a great location with fantastic views.

Montusi provides guided morning walks around the lodge's vast estate to beautiful spots such as Montusi Mountain and Bushman Cave. You can explore much of the stunning scenery around the amphitheatre by car, horse or mountain bike and these activities can also be arranged locally by the hotel staff.

You can take a township tour from Montusi to experience contemporary rural Zulu culture. These authentic tours are beneficial to this impoverished rural area. The tours are linked to the Khanyisela Project, which involves a scholarship programme for local children.

Today you move on to the historical Battlefields region. The drive to Fugitive's Drift Guesthouse will take just under four hours, passing through some of the most beautiful scenery in KwaZulu Natal. The Battlefields are historically significant due to the events during the Anglo-Boer war in the 19th Century. Your accommodation here is a family ran lodge owned by the Rattray family who offer amazing tours and also run the David Rattray foundation which offers charitable contributions to the local Zulu people.

Explore the Battlefields today - superb lecturers bring the Anglo-Zulu wars to life. The tours are utterly riveting and very informative. We recommend you start with Isandlwana today and then head to Rorke's Drift tomorrow. These tours are included for you with the great guides at Fugitive's Drift. The order of the tours replicates the events of the fateful day back in 1879.

Enjoy the tour of Rorke's Drift today and learn about this second important battlefield. This tour runs in the afternoon so this morning you could relax by the pool or enjoy a walk in the nature reserve surrounding the lodge which is home to various antelope species you can see!
Today you drive back to Durban airport, which will take around four hours. Here, you drop off your hire car and fly to Johannesburg and then overnight back to the UK.
You arrive home today.

tourName: Langebaan Lagoon sailing adventure, South Africa
generalInfo:
Embark on an unforgettable 3-day catamaran sailing adventure with Hobie Cape, set against the stunning landscapes of Langebaan. Your journey begins with a peaceful stay at the Greystone Beach House, located in the heart of Langebaan. This beautifully designed beach house offers the perfect blend of comfort and tranquility, with spacious rooms and panoramic views of the pristine coastline. After a day of adventure, relax in the serene environment of your stylish accommodation, with the ocean just steps away.

The following day, set sail aboard a Hobie catamaran, exploring the crystal-clear waters of Langebaan Lagoon. Known for its calm, turquoise waters and scenic beauty, the lagoon provides the perfect environment for sailing. Whether you're an experienced sailor or new to the sport, Hobie Cape ensures a smooth, enjoyable experience with their top-of-the-line equipment and expert guidance. The tranquil lagoon, surrounded by sandy shores and vibrant birdlife, offers a peaceful yet exciting sailing experience.

The scenic beauty of Langebaan, with its rugged coastline, picturesque beaches, and abundant wildlife, will captivate you throughout your trip. Spend your days gliding across the calm waters, taking in the breathtaking views, and soaking up the natural charm of this West Coast paradise.

This 3-day catamaran sailing trip combines adventure, relaxation, and incredible surroundings, offering the perfect escape to one of South Africa's most beautiful coastal destinations.

dayInfo.description: Your unforgettable 4-day catamaran sailing adventure begins as you arrive at Cape Town International Airport, greeted by your friendly transfer driver. Sit back and relax as you embark on a scenic drive to Langebaan, winding through picturesque countryside and breathtaking coastal views. The journey itself is a feast for the eyes, with rugged hills giving way to the serene blue waters of the Atlantic Ocean. Upon arrival at Greystone Beach House, you’ll be captivated by its charm and elegance. Nestled just steps from the beach, the house offers stunning views of the ocean and the surrounding natural beauty. With spacious, beautifully designed interiors, this beach house is your perfect home away from home. Once you’ve settled in, you’ll have the freedom to explore Langebaan at your leisure. Stroll along the beach, visit local shops, or venture into nearby restaurants to savor the flavors of the West Coast cuisine. The town’s laid-back atmosphere and scenic charm provide a relaxing backdrop for a peaceful evening. Retire to your comfortable room for a tranquil night’s rest, ready to begin your exciting catamaran sailing journey with Hobie Cape the next day.

Embark on your first day aboard the Hobie Cape catamaran, where the gentle ocean breeze welcomes you as you glide effortlessly across the sparkling waters. The catamaran offers the ideal combination of speed and tranquility, providing an exhilarating yet serene sailing experience. Feel the rush of the wind in your hair as you harness the power of the sails, while simultaneously savoring the peaceful atmosphere of the open sea. As you sail along the stunning coastline, the vivid blue of the ocean contrasts beautifully with the rugged cliffs and lush greenery of the shore, creating a picturesque setting that’s hard to forget. The sound of the waves lapping against the hull and the distant calls of seabirds fill the air as you venture into tranquil waters, offering moments of stillness and connection with nature.Throughout the day, you’ll have the chance to explore hidden coves and secluded beaches, accessible only by boat. Take time to swim, snorkel, or simply relax in these peaceful spots, soaking in the beauty and serenity of the surroundings.

On day three, your sailing adventure continues with a day of further exploration aboard the Hobie Cape catamaran. This time, you’ll venture further along the coast, uncovering hidden gems and secret spots that are only accessible by boat. As you glide through the pristine waters, you’ll feel the thrill of the wind filling the sails, propelling you forward as the catamaran moves effortlessly through the gentle waves. The experience is both invigorating and peaceful, offering the perfect balance of adventure and relaxation. Whether you're an experienced sailor or a first-time adventurer, the Hobie Cape catamarans are designed to cater to all levels, ensuring maximum comfort and excitement for everyone on board. The sleek design of the catamaran allows for a smooth ride, making it easy to take control and feel connected to the elements, or simply sit back and let the beauty of the coastline unfold before you.As you sail, take in panoramic views of the rugged coastline, with its dramatic cliffs and lush greenery. The sunlight reflects off the water, creating a shimmering effect that seems to dance across the waves. Throughout the day, you’ll be surrounded by the awe-inspiring beauty of nature, creating memories that will last a lifetime.

On the final day of your sailing adventure, set sail once again aboard the Hobie Cape catamaran for a day filled with pure sailing pleasure. The catamaran’s smooth ride and agility make gliding over the clear, turquoise waters an exhilarating experience. With every wave and gust of wind, the day offers a perfect blend of excitement and relaxation. Today, you’ll explore even more hidden gems along the coastline, discovering secluded coves and tranquil beaches that can only be reached by boat. Whether you’re soaking in the quiet beauty of the surroundings or enjoying the freedom of the open sea, this day will leave you feeling refreshed, invigorated, and deeply connected to nature. With the final sunset reflecting over the water, enjoy a peaceful stroll along the beach, before being transferred to Cape Town (CPT) to continue your journey towards further horizons.

tourName: NGO Photography Workshop in South Africa
generalInfo:
Are you a passionate photographer looking for a way to use your skills for good? If so, this nonprofit photography program might be a great fit. This program takes you on an educational journey around the impact that photography can have on the nonprofit sector. It’s a unique and immersive way to visit South Africa, and a great way to challenge yourself as a photographer and greatly enrich your portfolio. Applications are now open!

This program will take you to the South African town of Stellenbosch, just outside of Cape Town; a stunning area and a great base for our photography work. We'll be shooting at grassroots nonprofits in the surrounding communities; quite rural communities that are underserved and deal with a great amount of social issues. We'll be working with impactful projects working in education, skill development, female empowerment, food security, animal welfare, and more.

As a nonprofit photographer, your images are important to the nonprofit organizations you’ll be working with, as they usually don't have strong visual media to tell their stories. By providing them with a database of strong images, we help them raise awareness for their cause, and reach potential donors. Visual storytelling can be key in an organisation's success.

You'll receive constant tutoring by Anna Lusty, a professional photographer specialised in humanitarian photography. She'll provide both theoretical and practical workshops that cover all the elements of nonprofit photography, so that you'll be well prepared and fully supported.

To join this nonprofit photography workshop, you'll need to have a good camera and intermediate photography skills. If you have this - as well as a passion for humanitarian work - we'd love to see your application!

dayInfo.description: You’ll arrive on a Sunday, and we'll meet you at the airport in Cape Town! You’ll have time to settle into your bed & breakfast in Stellenbosch. This day is yours to settle in, unwind, and prepare for the upcoming days ahead.

These next few days will be dedicated to learning about nonprofit photography to prepare for your upcoming photography projects with nonprofit organizations. You’ll join a photography workshop, where you’ll gain insight into the different aspects of nonprofit photography, including preparation for shoots, ethics of photography, and how to properly document the work of the organizations. Alongside this, you’ll also have the opportunity to refine your overall photography skills with our expert photographer and your fellow participants.
The weekends are yours to explore and explore your surroundings.

During the second week, you'll be taking on shoots at various nonprofit organizations, usually with one or two other photographers. There will be plenty of time in between photography shoots for sessions on post-productions, reflection, and further workshops by Anna.
Saturday is another day to relax or enjoy Stellenbosch, Cape Town, or the surrounding wine lands.
Departure day! We'll say our goodbyes and take you back to Cape Town Airport.

tourName: Nine day wildlife safari, South Africa
placesVisited: Rukiya Safari Camp, Unique 'bush senses' experience, Bush walks, Help Ingwe Leopard Research Team set camera traps, Wild Rivers Reserve, Private concession in Balule Reserve, Klaserie Game Reserve, Thornybush Game Reserve
generalInfo:
This exciting 9-day safari visits a variety of private game reserves in the greater Kruger Park area, as well as the world-renowned Kruger National Park. The base for this safari is in Wild Rivers Nature Reserve, but this holiday also takes in Klaserie and Thornybush game reserves, which all offer different accommodation and habitat types, for a fully rounded safari experience. This package includes an introduction to learn more about of work in Leopard conservation, plus even more chances to view the Big Five and explore the African bush. It’s the perfect combination of exploring the African bush, learning about our conservation work and enjoying high quality accommodation in fantastic locations.

We are a small company and prefer small groups of less than eight persons, which allow us to deliver a personal service, with flexibility to cater for any specific needs. Whether you’re here for general wildlife viewing or interested in something specific we can help. In addition, you might like to visit one of our community projects. Choose to be hands-on or simply sit back and let us take the strain. Whatever you prefer, we’ll do our best to provide. Just let us know what you want from your safari experience and together we can make your time with us truly memorable.

This 9-day safari runs all year round and is also available for families. Children under 12 years get 50% off the adult price. Bush walks are replaced by game drives for children under 14 years.

Where possible we provide an all-inclusive price for each safari, with any additions clearly shown on your itinerary. That’s because we understand how important it is to plan your safari costs and avoid any hidden extras.

dayInfo.description: Arrival at Hoedspruit & Welcome to Rukiya Hoedspruit (Eastgate) Airport is the gateway to South Africa’s premier wildlife viewing reserves, with daily flights arriving from Johannesburg and Cape Town. We can arrange your internal flight to Hoedspruit (approximately 50 minutes). Upon landing, you'll be greeted by your On Track Safaris (OTS) representative and transferred to Rukiya Safari Camp. Keep an eye out as you drive past game fences—your first wildlife sightings may happen before you even unpack! No matter how you arrive, you'll reach Rukiya Safari Camp in time to settle in, unwind, and enjoy the tranquil surroundings. You’ll also receive a reusable On Track Safaris metal water bottle to help reduce plastic use during your stay, along with a spoor card to help identify animal tracks during game drives and bush walks—be sure to keep it handy! Rukiya is a small, luxury eco-tented camp nestled along the banks of the year-round Blyde River, shaded by towering trees. It’s also an important location for our leopard research, making your visit part of a meaningful conservation effort. Depending on your arrival time, lunch will be served, followed by an optional afternoon drive through the Wild Rivers Reserve. Don’t forget to order your sundowner drinks for the perfect end to your first day. At Rukiya, you’ll receive a complimentary camera trap (one per couple or single guest) as a gift from On Track Safaris. On your first day, with guidance from our expert team, you’ll choose a location on the reserve where you believe leopards and other wildlife may pass. These motion-sensitive devices capture photos or short videos of animals—day or night—offering a thrilling glimpse into their natural behaviour. Camera Trap Challenge Capturing Africa’s wildlife with a camera trap is both exciting and deeply rewarding. Begin by selecting a location frequented by animals—such as watering holes, game trails, or mineral licks—where wildlife naturally congregates. While our guides are there to assist, the final choice is yours. Your camera will be securely mounted to a tree or post at animal height and angled slightly downward for optimal shots. Equipped with infrared technology, it operates silently to avoid disturbing nocturnal creatures. The camera will run continuously throughout your stay, capturing candid moments of Africa’s untamed beauty. These will be checked before departing Rukiya. After dinner at the lodge, you’ll likely retire early to your tent, ready for your first early morning rise and the adventures ahead.

A Day at Rukiya Safari Camp Your days at Rukiya begin with a gentle wake-up call, accompanied by a warm drink and traditional rusks (local biscuits) to start your morning. You'll then set off on a morning game drive through the Wild Rivers Reserve and into the adjacent Balule Reserve, part of the Greater Kruger National Park. This marks your first adventure in a 'Big5' Reserve. These drives may extend longer than usual, often including a bush breakfast served in the wild, before returning to the lodge in the late morning. Lunch is served at the lodge, followed by time to unwind and take in the tranquil views from your private deck. Bush Senses Experience During your stay, you'll have the chance to participate in our unique Bush Senses activity—a short guided walk paired with a sensory exercise developed over many years. This popular experience encourages you to engage all your senses in the bush: not just sight, but also smell, hearing, and touch. In a world where modern living dulls our natural instincts, this simple and fun activity helps sharpen your awareness—perfect preparation for any safari. Conservation & Camera Trap Check You’ll also be invited to attend a fascinating presentation by the Ingwe Leopard Research Team, offering insight into the vital conservation work happening right on the reserve. In the afternoon, your PM drive will explore the Wild Rivers Reserve, possibly passing by your camera trap to ensure it’s still in place. Curious hyenas and baboons are known to tamper with these devices—sometimes even taking selfies before abandoning them in the bush. The resulting photos are often hilarious and a highlight of the trip. Evening at the Lodge After your afternoon adventure, dinner will be served at the lodge, offering a chance to reflect on the day’s sightings and stories under the African sky.

Meet the Anti-Poaching Dog Unit & Visit a Community Project Today offers a well-earned break from early morning game drives, allowing you to enjoy a leisurely start before breakfast. Afterward, you'll embark on a meaningful day excursion, beginning with a visit to the K9 Conservation Group, followed by lunch and an afternoon at Zingela Ulwazi, a local community initiative. K9 Conservation Group The K9 Conservation Group provides vital anti-poaching support to privately owned conservation areas and game reserves through the deployment of elite, highly trained working dog units. You'll meet some of the dedicated rangers and their remarkable canine partners, and learn about the critical role they play in protecting wildlife. A highlight of the visit includes heading into the nearby bush for a live demonstration. Watch as the dogs expertly locate poachers’ snares and track human scent—an eye-opening experience that showcases their incredible skills and intelligence. They’re not only impressive but also a joy to be around. After the demonstration, enjoy lunch at a local café (at your own expense). Zingela Ulwazi Community Project In the afternoon, you'll visit Zingela Ulwazi, a grassroots non-profit focused on empowering rural women through sustainable farming, self-defense training, and community upliftment. During your visit, you’ll explore their inspiring projects, meet the women leading change, and see firsthand how small initiatives can make a big impact. To end the visit, we’ll stop by a lively community hub where children gather after school. You’ll have the opportunity to help serve lunch and share in the warmth of their daily routine—a heartwarming experience that connects you to the spirit of the community. Return via Hoedspruit On your way back to Rukiya, we’ll pass through the charming town of Hoedspruit, where you can opt to stop for a bit of shopping or continue directly to the lodge, arriving in the late afternoon. Dinner will be served in the evening, rounding off a day filled with purpose, connection, and unforgettable encounters.

Your day begins with a gentle wake-up call, accompanied by a warm drink and traditional rusks (local biscuits) to start your morning. You'll then set off on a morning game drive through the Wild Rivers Reserve and into the adjacent Balule Reserve, part of the Greater Kruger National Park. This marks your first adventure in a 'Big5' Reserve. These drives may extend longer than usual, often including a bush breakfast served in the wild, before returning to the lodge in the late morning. Lunch is served at the lodge, followed by time to unwind and take in the tranquil views from your private deck. Camera Trap Review & Riverside Relaxation On your return from the morning game drive you'll collect your camera trap and return to the lodge, where—assisted by your guides—you’ll review the photographs it captured. You're welcome to download any images you’d like to keep. If you’ve managed to photograph a leopard, those images will be added to the Ingwe Research Program database, contributing to our ongoing conservation efforts. You’ll also have the option to donate your camera trap to support further research, or—as many guests choose—take it home to continue your wildlife photography adventures. Afternoon Leisure After lunch, enjoy some well-deserved downtime. Grab a cooler box with refreshing drinks and head to our outdoor lounger area along the riverbank. It’s the perfect spot to soak in the peace and quiet of this serene setting, watch birds flitting through the trees, and perhaps spot a hippo or crocodile basking on the opposite bank. Evening Dining Dinner will be served in the evening, rounding off a day of discovery and relaxation in the heart of the bush.

Transfer to Nzumba, Klaserie Game Reserve After a leisurely breakfast and check-out, your vehicle will arrive to transfer you to Nzumba Lodge, located within the renowned Klaserie Game Reserve—a destination celebrated for its exceptional Big Five sightings and premium wildlife experiences. As you travel through the reserve, keep your eyes open for wildlife along the way. Upon arrival at the lodge, you'll be welcomed with a refreshing drink and complete a brief indemnity form. You’ll then have time to settle in, unwind, and enjoy the tranquil surroundings before afternoon high tea is served. Afternoon & Evening Game Drive Later in the day, you'll head out on an afternoon game drive, pausing for sundowner drinks as the sun dips below the horizon. Once darkness falls, your guide will use a spotlight to help you seek out nocturnal animals—a thrilling opportunity to witness the bush come alive after sunset. You’ll return to the lodge for a delicious dinner, rounding off your first evening in Klaserie with stories and sightings from the wild.

Safari Days at Klaserie Game Reserve No two days on safari are ever the same—and your next two days in Klaserie Game Reserve promise fresh discoveries and unforgettable moments. Each morning begins with an early game drive, offering prime opportunities to spot wildlife in the cool hours of the day. You'll return to the lodge in time for a hearty breakfast, followed by a chance to rest and relax during the midday heat. It’s the perfect time to unwind and watch animals wander past from the comfort of the lodge. In the afternoon, after high tea, you'll head out on another game drive, exploring new and previously unseen areas of the reserve. As the sun sets, you’ll pause for sundowner drinks, then continue your drive into the evening, when nocturnal creatures begin to stir. Dinner is often served around the fire in the outdoor boma, under a canopy of stars—a fitting end to a day immersed in the wild.

?? Final Morning in Klaserie On your last morning in Klaserie Game Reserve, you'll set out on a final game drive, exploring areas of the concession not yet visited. It’s a chance to capture those last memorable photographs and soak in the beauty of the bush one more time before returning to the lodge for breakfast. Departure & Transfer After breakfast, your On Track Safaris (OTS) representative will collect you for your transfer to Hoedspruit Airport(approximately 90 minutes). You’ll arrive in time to check in for your departure flight, marking the end of your unforgettable safari adventure.

tourName: Self-drive trip into Limpopo, South Africa
