placesVisited: Johannesburg, Welgevonden Game Reserve, Three nights at Kololo Game Reserve, Game drives and Big Five, Soutpansberg Mountains, Two nights Madi a Thavha Lodge, Visit craft workshops, Three nights Mopane Bush Lodge, Mapungubwe National Park and World Heritage Site, Two nights Leshiba Wilderness game reserve, Rock art sites, Game drives, guided walks and horse riding
generalInfo:
This tailor made, 12 day self-drive trip takes you into Limpopo, one of South Africa's most beautiful, but least visited provinces. Here, you’ll discover diverse wildlife, dramatic scenery, a long history and a vibrant traditional arts scene. This is a place of seemingly endless savannahs, craggy mountains, wildlife reserves, wonderful accommodation and traditional villages.

Enjoy a wealth of different experiences on this trip, from spotting the Big Five in Welgevonden Game Reserve (which is also malaria free) to enjoying the sandstone landscapes, ancient baobab trees and herds of African wildlife in Mapungubwe National Park, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. While at Mapungubwe, you can also see ancient rock paintings made by San bushmen and climb to the confluence viewpoint alongside the Limpopo River to see where South Africa, Botswana and Zimbabwe meet. Learn about the Venda and Tsonga traditions and lifestyles while staying in the Soutpansberg Mountains and at Leshiba Wilderness, stay in the remarkable Venda Village Lodge, a unique place full of sculpture and artworks, created with acclaimed Venda artist, Noria Mabasa.

This is a wonderful tour through the fascinating Limpopo region, with drive times of no more than four hours and frequently much less, and several days spent at each of the four unique accommodations, so you have time to relax and explore.

dayInfo.description: Depart on your overnight flight to Johannesburg.

Arrive Johannesburg, you collect your car and drive into the malarial-free Welgevonden Game Reserve for a 3 night stay at Kololo Game Reserve. Kololo Game Reserve offers a varied African safari experience a mere 3,5 hours drive from Johannesburg. Kololo is situated in the beautiful, malaria-free Waterberg area and affords guests the chance of seeing a wide variety of free ranging wildlife including giraffe, kudu, zebra, eland and impala. Enjoy game drives, walks or a mountain bike ride assisted by Kololo’s friendly and knowledgeable rangers. Part of Kololo is integrated into Welgevonden Game Reserve, a Big Five region. Here elephant, rhino, lion, leopard and buffalo abound along with a range of other animals and an abundance of birds. Accommodation types vary from chalets and villas to the tented camp. Relax at the pool, enjoy a bush braai or sip a drink while soaking in the splendour of the African bushveld view from the lookout decks.
Today you drive back to Johannesburg airport, where you drop off your car in time for your return flight home.

tourName: Snorkelling and diving holiday, South Africa
generalInfo:
Your journey begins the moment you land in Cape Town—where ocean mist mingles with mountain air and Table Mountain rises proudly over a city alive with natural beauty. After arrival, you'll be met by our trusted transport partner and transferred to your first expediton. You’ll have the opportunity to ease into the underwater world with a guided scuba and snorkeling experience at the Two Oceans Aquarium—an ideal setting to gain confidence as you meet vibrant marine life up close.

Thereafter, you will be transferred to your accomodation for the next two days, a boathouse! With wooden decks overlooking the sea and interiors inspired by nautical elegance, the boathouse is a haven of comfort and calm. Afternoons and evenings are yours to enjoy at leisure. Simon’s Town, with it's historic streets, cozy cafes and the beloved penguin colony at Boulders Beach, offers a perfect mix of charm and discovery.

Day Two takes a bold turn as you’re privately transferred for a heart-pounding shark cage diving excursion. With expert guides by your side, you’ll come face-to-face with the ocean’s most iconic predator in a safe, respectful environment. On Day Three, venture into the wild waters of the Atlantic for an unforgettable snorkeling experience in Cape Town’s kelp forests. Surrounded by towering fronds and darting fish, this ethereal underwater world is both serene and exhilarating.Your final night is spent at the elegant President Hotel in Sea Point.

Take a sunset stroll along the Sea Point Promenade, breathe in the ocean air, and let the view of waves meeting sky etch a lasting memory. With expert support, premium accommodation and unparalleled marine experiences, this journey is more than a holiday — it’s an awakening of the soul beneath the sea.

dayInfo.description: Upon arrival in Cape Town, you’ll be warmly greeted by Hannivals Tours, our trusted transport partner, ready to escort you along scenic coastal roads where mountains meet the sea. Your first taste of the ocean’s magic begins at the renowned Two Oceans Aquarium, where an extraordinary diving adventure awaits. Immerse yourself in a world teeming with vibrant marine life—graceful rays, darting fish, and shimmering shoals surround you in a safe, awe-inspiring environment, offering the perfect introduction to the wonders beneath the waves. After a morning of discovery, you will be transferred to your accommodation for the next two nights: a charming boathouse in Simon’s Town. Perched along the quiet shores of False Bay, the boathouse offers an inviting blend of rustic charm and coastal elegance, where ocean breezes and panoramic views create an atmosphere of pure tranquility.The afternoon is yours to enjoy at leisure. Wander the historic streets of Simon’s Town, visit the famous African penguin colony at Boulders Beach, or savor a seaside meal overlooking the bustling harbor. As the sun dips behind the mountains, retreat to your exquisite boathouse for a peaceful night’s rest, lulled by the soft sound of waves and the promise of adventures yet to come.

Awaken to the gentle hush of waves lapping against the pilings of your cozy boathouse hideaway, where the morning sun spills golden light across the still waters of Simon’s Town harbour. The air is crisp with salt and promise, seabirds wheel overhead, and the mountains rise in soft silhouette beyond. After a peaceful breakfast, a short transfer brings you to African Shark Eco-Charters, where an unforgettable experience awaits: shark cage diving in the heart of Cape Town’s wild waters. Choose from the early 07:30 thrill or the more relaxed 11:30 departure. After a warm welcome and expert briefing, you’ll set off on a 3.5-hour adventure guided by an enthusiastic and highly experienced crew. Muffins, fresh fruit, snacks, and hot drinks keep you fueled while you suit up with top-tier scuba gear for a safe, awe-inspiring face-to-face with the ocean’s apex predators. After your return, wind down with a transfer back to your boathouse. The rest of the day is yours. Meander through the quaint charm of Simon’s Town, perhaps dining at local gems like The Lighthouse Café or Bertha’s. As evening falls, take a slow stroll along the shoreline, where the sunset paints the sea in fire and gold.

Awake to the gentle hush of waves in your cozy boathouse in Simon’s Town, where the morning light spills over False Bay and seabirds wheel overhead. After a hearty breakfast, you’ll be transferred along the coast to Sea Point — a vibrant seaside suburb where the Atlantic kisses the edge of Cape Town. Here, your aquatic adventure begins with a guided snorkeling experience led by the passionate team at Into the Blue. Renowned for their focus on safety, local knowledge, and ecological sensitivity, Into the Blue selects daily snorkel sites based on optimal conditions, ensuring you have the best visibility and experience. Your entry point is the shoreline itself — no boats, just a wade into the wild. No prior snorkeling experience is necessary, though you should be confident in the water. With all equipment provided, you’ll spend 1–2 unforgettable hours gliding through the kelp forests, a swaying undersea wonderland teeming with life, color, and quiet magic. After your dive, you’ll be whisked away to check in at the President Hotel, perched along the scenic Sea Point Promenade. This iconic Cape Town establishment offers more than a place to rest your head — it’s a sanctuary of comfort and style, with panoramic ocean views, a chic outdoor pool, and refined dining. Settle in, watch the sunset over the Atlantic, and toast your penultimate night with the rhythm of the waves just beyond your window.

Your final morning in Cape Town begins with quiet beauty—an early walk along the Sea Point Promenade as the sun crests the horizon, casting soft amber light across the Atlantic. The ocean stretches endlessly before you, waves glinting like molten gold, and seabirds wheel in the gentle breeze. It’s a peaceful moment of reflection, the perfect way to greet your last day on this unforgettable journey. Back at The President Hotel, a sumptuous breakfast awaits—fresh pastries, tropical fruits, rich coffee, and warm dishes crafted with care. It's a final taste of Cape Town's culinary charm, savored slowly as you gaze out at the sea one last time.Shortly after, our trusted travel partner, Hannival’s Travels, will collect you for a seamless and comfortable transfer from The President Hotel to Cape Town International Airport. As you ride through the city one final time, the memories of vibrant reefs, close encounters, sun-warmed afternoons, and ocean breezes linger warmly.At the airport, the journey continues—not just to your next destination, but into new horizons, with the spirit of the sea carried in your heart. This is more than a trip; it’s a story you’ll tell for years to come.

tourName: South Africa and Swaziland safari holiday
placesVisited: Johannesburg, St Lucia, Hluhluwe-iMfolozi Game Reserve, St Lucia Wetland Reserve, Mlilwane Wildlife Sanctuary (Eswatini), Kruger National Park, whale watching opportunities in June and November
generalInfo:
To get to know South Africa you need an itinerary that takes in its epic landscapes, brings you face to face with its majestic nature, and gives you vivid accounts of its history. This tour is a great combination of all three – with a chance to visit eSwatini, too. It starts in Johannesburg and ends in the Kruger.

South Africa has some of the largest and most wildlife-heavy safari destinations in the world. The highlight of this tour is the unmatchable Kruger National Park, where animal lovers will be in heaven. You’ll also visit Africa’s largest rhino population in Hluhluwe iMfolozi. This trip gives you opportunities to engage with the inspirational conservation work done by game reserves to protect and advocate for their wildlife.

This trip also gives you time to explore the vast and dramatic landscapes of southern Africa: you’ll go hiking in the Drakensberg Mountains and visit the Zululand battlefields, and in eSwatini drive through the picturesque Ezulwini Valley.

Little eSwatini – formerly known as Swaziland – is less visited than surrounding South Africa. This is one of the world’s last absolute monarchies ruled by a king who has bene in power since 1986. In eSwatini you’ll get a change to visit Mlilwane, where an absence of dangerous animals means that you can do walking safaris. This is a pretty setting for wildlife watching, set as it is beneath the natural bowl of the Nyonyane Mountains.

This holiday covers some large distances, so be prepared to drive – after all, you’re discovering two countries with very big landscapes.

dayInfo.title: Join trip Johannesburg Airport; drive to the Drakensberg Mountains
dayInfo.description: : Our tour starts today in Johannesburg, South Africa's largest city, once home to both Nelson Mandela and Desmond Tutu. Your tour leader will meet you at 10:30 in the arrival hall at O.R. Tambo International Airport (JNB) and we aim to depart no later than 11.30am. From the airport, we'll drive southeast to the Drakensberg Mountains (a journey of around four-and-a-half hours). Drakensberg is the world's oldest mountain range, deriving its name from the Afrikaans word for 'Dragon Mountains'; in the mist, the razor-back ridges of the mountains have a likeness to these mythical beasts. Upon arrival to our accommodation, there might be time to take a short walk in the surrounding nature. If you're booking your own flights to Johannesburg, we recommend giving yourself plenty of time to clear the airport. The latest your flight can arrive is 10.30am.

dayInfo.title: Walk in Drakensberg World Heritage Site
dayInfo.description: : This morning, after a hearty breakfast, we'll have the opportunity to join a guided walk and experience the beauty of the mountain range first-hand. The full walk takes around four to five hours and we've graded it as moderate-to-challenging. The walk itself is approximately 8km long, but can be shortened for those preferring a more gentle option. Weather permitting, upon returning to our hotel, our guide will have prepared a tasty 'al fresco' lunch for us to enjoy while we soak up the spectacular views of the Drakensberg. The afternoon is left free to either relax whilst enjoying a cool drink or perhaps continue our adventure with an easy walk through the mountain valleys to view a rock carving close to camp.

dayInfo.title: Visit battlefields; drive on to St Lucia
dayInfo.description: : We'll set off early this morning and head to the famous battlefield of Rorke's Drift, arriving around mid-morning. Portrayed in the 1964 movie Zulu , the battle at Rorke's Drift was a bloody and hugely significant battle in the history of the Zulu nation, depicting the 1879 battle between the local Zulu and the British Army. Although time is limited today, due to the distance we have to travel, our tour leader will take time to explain the importance of these clashes in relation to South Africa's history, British colonialism and the Zulu people. After a lunch stop, we'll drive for the rest of the afternoon to St Lucia, our base for the next three nights.

dayInfo.title: Game Drives in Hluhluwe-iMfolozi Game Reserve
dayInfo.description: : We'll have another early start this morning to take advantage of the 'golden hour' on a Big 5 safari in one of Africa's oldest game reserves. Hluhluwe-iMfolozi Park boasts the densest population of both white and black rhinos in the whole of Africa. We'll have our breakfast at one of the reserve's picnic sites, where we can stretch our legs and freshen up before continuing our safari journey. With over 500 species of birds recorded at this reserve, it's also a paradise for any birdwatchers amongst us. In the afternoon, we'll return to St. Lucia where we'll have the opportunity to experience the optional activity of a 'Hippo Cruise' on the Greater St. Lucia Estuary. The cruise meanders along allowing us to relax whilst viewing the hippos and crocodiles in their natural habitat as the sun drops from the African sky. Other activities includes a bicycle tour, a turtle safari (in season only) and an evening game drive in Isimangaliso Wetland reserve.

dayInfo.title: At St Lucia Wetland Reserve
dayInfo.description: : Today you're free to choose from one of several optional activities. There is the opportunity to continue our game-viewing experience by taking a leisurely open game drive in the iSimangaliso Wetland Park, which was the first World Heritage Site in South Africa and home to four of the Big 5. The word iSimangaliso means miracle and wonder, which aptly describes this truly unique place. This optional activity also includes a typical 'braai' lunch at Cape Vidal. There is also the chance explore the local forest hiking trails. In the evening, you can enjoy an exhilarating night game drive when all the nocturnal wildlife start their day. From November to February, we can join a guided turtle tour in the Wetland.

dayInfo.title: Drive to Eswatini
dayInfo.description: : This morning, we'll make our way to Eswatini, from June to November we may have the opportunity to participate in the optional activity of whale watching, the St. Lucia coastline is the optimal location to view Humpback whales as they make their way up the coastline to Mozambique to breed. We'll then drive north and enter Eswatini - a tiny, independent kingdom inhabited by the Swazi tribe who revere their king and take great pride in retaining their culture and traditions. Along the way, we can soak up the spectacular scenery of the Ezulwini Valley, dotted with traditional homesteads. Once we have arrived safely in the Kingdom of Eswatini we will make our first rest stop at the artisan craft market at Swazi Candles near Malkerns. Famous across the world for their colorful and beautiful wax candle designs a visit here is a great way to interact with the local artisinal craftsmen and to witness first hand how so simple as a wax candle can support a whole community. In the late afternoon, we'll enter one of Eswatini's best wildlife reserves, Mlilwane Wildlife Sanctuary. This secluded and beautiful sanctuary is a haven of tranquillity, located in a natural bowl beneath the Nyonyane Mountains. For the next two nights, we'll stay in traditional dome-shaped beehive huts set in a wooded area. Though the camp has all the mod cons - showers, toilets, outdoor swimming pool and restaurant and bar - it is rustic in the best sense of the word. Warthogs, nyala and antelope share the camp with us, and the restaurant overlooks a lake populated by water birds, crocodiles and terapins. Due to the high demand in Mlilwane, accommodation is subject to change without notice and can vary in style. We'll endeavour to stay within the park when possible, however, some departures may be staying up to a 15-minute drive from the sanctuary in a hotel or guesthouse.

dayInfo.title: Game viewing and optional activities in Mlilwane Wildlife Sanctuary
dayInfo.description: : Mlilwane is Eswatini's oldest protected area, owned and managed by a non-profit making trust, it is situated in the low foothills of the Nyonyane Mountains. The park has been rehabilitated to become Eswatini's most frequented reserve where you can enjoy the beauty of the surroundings and the abundant wildlife that calls these plains home. Mlilwane has a large area of open grassland making game viewing and bird watching relatively easy and this morning we'll begin with a walk in search of zebra, wildebeest, nyala and warthog. The afternoon is free to choose one of the optional activities available at the reserve, the absence of big cats allows us to partake in mountain biking or trail walking in a relaxed setting. The alternatives are to accompany our guide to the local village of Mantenga, a living-museum to learn more about the Swazi people, their traditions and their culture, or you could simple relax and sit back to watch the local wildlife grazing outside our very own front door.

dayInfo.title: Drive to Kruger National Park
dayInfo.description: : After an early start, we'll drive north re-entering South Africa and crossing the Crocodile River into the Kruger National Park. This two-million-hectare wilderness is amongst the world's first proclaimed National Park and is justifiably South Africa's showpiece, boasting over 145 mammal species. The park offers the Big 5 and over 500 recorded bird species along with scenery as diverse as riverine forest, granite outcrops, endless savannah and impenetrable mopani woodland. We'll take a game drive on our way to the accommodation where we'll stay overnight. We will be staying just outside the park gates at a newly designed modernistic property offering a fantastic location with all the amenities required and will be enjoying a typical african braai on the patio before getting an early night.

dayInfo.title: Game viewing in Kruger National Park; drive to Graskop
dayInfo.description: : The Kruger National Park was established in 1898 to protect big game that had been hunted to near extinction. Today it is one of South Africa's most prolific wildlife habitats and a leader in animal conservation. We'll set out very early for a full day in the park, beginning with game viewing at various watering holes where we might see buffalo or antelope taking an early morning drink and, with luck, a pride of lions nearby. Midday we'll pause for lunch at one of the park's restaurants before continuing our safari in the afternoon, heading towards the Sabie River. This is a major water source for the park's wildlife and an excellent spot for game viewing. After a rewarding day exploring Kruger, we'll leave the park mid-afternoon and climb more than 1,000 metres to our overnight stop at Graskop.

dayInfo.title: Drive to O.R. Tambo International Airport (JNB) where our trip ends
dayInfo.description: : Departing around 7am this morning, we'll drive back to Johannesburg (a journey time of seven hours). Along the way, we'll drive through the airy uplands of Mpumalanga, an area that has been inhabited since the Stone Age and boasts rivers, multiple waterfalls, craggy escarpments and colourful birdlife. We'll stop at several viewpoints, including the aptly named 'God's Window' and admire the awe-inspiring Blyde River Canyon. We'll arrive at O.R. Tambo International Airport (JNB) at around 5pm and this is where our trip ends. The earliest your flight can depart is 7.20pm.

tourName: South Africa and Swaziland safari
placesVisited: Mpumalanga, Kruger National Park, Big Five game drives, Malolotja Nature Reserve, Swaziland, Mzuki Game Reserve, Zulu culture, Walking in Drakensberg Mountains - uKhalamba, Wild Coast, Nelson Mandela's burial site, Addo Elephant National Park, Knysna, Tsitsikamma Forest, Hermanus, Land-based whale watching (in season), Cape Town, Stellenbosch, Climbing Table Mountain, Cape Point, Optional: Robben Island tour
generalInfo:
The Rainbow Route is an overview tour of South Africa including neighbouring Kingdom of Swaziland/eSwatini. The tour covers many highlights with a strong focus on the national parks. This diverse country is explored over great distances that may involve long days on the road, generally followed by a full day to experience the area. The fully accommodated tour offers a great value for money way to explore South Africa.

DEPARTS: JOHANNESBURG on Saturday at06:30am, ENDS: CAPE TOWN on Monday at +/-18:00pm.

Highlights
* Kruger National Park–game drives
* Swaziland/eSwatini–mountain walks
* Zululand–game drives & cultural village
* Drakensberg Mountains–mountain walks
* Wild Coast–beach walks & Xhosa culture
*Garden Route–forest walks, beaches and whales
* Cape Town–Cape Point & Table Mountain

Overnight - 16 nights on safari we stay at small lodges and guest houses, with en suite facilities. Meals - 16 breakfasts, 12 lunches and 10 dinners are included. Of which 12 breakfasts & 6 dinners are provided by the lodge. The remaining included meals are provided by the crew, prepared at the vehicle and eaten around the campfire or in a boma or dining area. Transport we use custom-built Safari trucks with 12 forward facing seats. The vehicles are comfortable for cruising and excellent for game viewing with large sliding windows and front hatches for ease of viewing. On5% of tours we may use Mercedes Sprinter minibuses with 12 seats and air conditioning (with trailer for equipment and baggage). There are several long days of travel providing for a beautiful journey on the way to exciting and varied destinations. Limited participation an essential part of your safari is some participation. From carrying your own bag to cleaning your window and packing the truck in the morning–it’s all part of your adventure and when everyone puts in a little effort the trip will run smoothly (especially on the longer days). Where the tour leaders provide meals, we ask that clients help (on rotation) with the washing up.

dayInfo.description: JOHANNESBURG to GREATER KRUGER: Departing from Johannesburg at 06:30am we head towards Mpumalanga where mountains, panoramic passes, valleys, rivers, waterfalls & forests characterise the landscape. We enjoy the views from God’s Window before descending off the escarpment and heading to our game lodge on the border of the Greater Kruger NP. The following morning, we are up early for a full day of game viewing in Kruger National Park. We will return to our lodge in the late afternoon to enjoy sunset over the Drakensberg Mountains, a swim in the pool and a hearty meal before falling asleep to the sounds of Africa. [lodge Bx1 Lx2 Dx2]

KINGDOM OF eSWATINI (SWAZILAND): Malolotja Nature Reserve in the mountainous Kingdom of eSwatini (Swaziland) is our next attraction. Renowned for a great variety of habitats from short grassland, to thick riverine scrub, bushveld and moist forest, we explore the reserve on foot to enjoy the fantastic mountain views. Relax around a campfire dinner and stay in mountain cabins for the night. [chalet BLD]

ADDO ELEPHANT NATIONAL PARK: The Addo Elephant National Park was established in 1931 to protect the last 11 wild elephants from extermination. Today more than 600 elephants roam through the area. The park also offers excellent viewing of black rhino, Cape buffalo, lion and leopard, as well as a host of other large and small mammals and over 400 species of birds in the greater park area. [chalet B - D]

HERMANUS: Hermanus offers some of the best land-based whale watching in the world. From June to November Southern Right whales come up from the southern oceans to calve and mate in the shallow waters around the Cape. In whale season we will take a walk along this beautiful coastline. In the summer months we will explore the flowering fynbos in Fernkloof Nature Reserve. Enjoy an evening meal out at a local restaurant (own expense). [guest house B - -]

TOUR ENDS: In the morning we climb Table Mountain, offering panoramic views over Cape Town reaching out into the bay and Robben Island. Having explored the highlights of the Rainbow Nation we take a last look at Cape Town and catch up on last minute curio shopping in the afternoon, before your tour ends at 18:00 at the hotel. [ - B - -]

tourName: South Africa and Zimbabwe holiday, tailor made
placesVisited: South Africa: Cape Town, Kruger National Park Zambia and Zimbabwe: Livingstone, Hotel at Victoria Falls, River cruise on Zambezi, Hwange National Park, Bulaweyo, Matobo Hills
generalInfo:
This South Africa and Zimbabwe holiday is a tailor made trip, following an itinerary that includes several days in some of our highly recommended places, staying in stunning accommodation from luxury hotel rooms to safari camps. The itinerary below is just a suggested one based on years of experience of what has worked well for our guests, but we are able to tweak it to suit your interests, budget and timeframe.

Start in Cape Town, with four nights to take in this cosmopolitan city with one of the most stunning locations in the world. From here you take a domestic flight up to Kruger National Park where you have three nights at a private game reserve staying in a luxury suite. The locations just keep getting better and better on this trip, your next highlight being Victoria Falls which you access via a flight to Livingstone in Zambia, the falls forming a natural border with Zimbabwe. The best view of the iconic falls is from the Zimbabwe side and during your time here you also get a chance to take on some of the region’s famous adventures, ranging from bungee jumping to a cruise down the Zambezi.

More wildlife adventures await at Hwange National Park, also in Zimbabwe, and which is famous for its enormous elephant population as well as buffalo, giraffe, wildebeest and impala. There are over a hundred mammals here in fact, and you will be staying in the heart of it at a safari camp, a highlight for many of our guests.

Your trip draws to a close staying in another incredible bush camp, this one part of a private estate outside Bulawayo, from where you can enjoy wildlife watching but also rhino tracking on foot, visiting Matobo Hills National Park, seeing San rock art, and bird watching.

dayInfo.description: Spend four unforgettable days in Cape Town exploring its iconic highlights. Start with Table Mountain for sweeping views, then wander the V&A Waterfront’s shops and restaurants. Visit Robben Island to learn its powerful history, and explore colorful Bo-Kaap. Drive the scenic Cape Peninsula to Cape Point and Boulders Beach’s penguins. Conclude with wine tasting in Stellenbosch or Franschhoek. Cape Town blends nature, culture, cuisine, and adventure perfectly.

Experience three adrenaline-packed days in Kruger National Park. Begin with an afternoon game drive, spotting elephants, giraffes, and predators. Day two takes you deep into Big Five territory: buffalo herds being followed by lion; elephant herds playing at waterholes - while expert guides reveal hidden secrets of the bush. Pause for bush picnics beneath endless African skies, and sundowners as the daylight disappears. Every turn offers suspense—lion tracks in the dust, a leopard draped in a tree, rhinos grazing in the open. On your final morning, a sunrise drive heightens the excitement as nocturnal predators retreat and the bush comes alive. End with brunch at camp, still buzzing from Kruger’s wild intensity.

With two nights at Victoria Falls, you can experience one of the world’s most spectacular natural wonders in style and adventure. Start your first day with a guided tour of the falls, feeling the mist on your face and capturing breathtaking photos from viewpoints like the Knife-Edge Bridge. In the afternoon, take a sunset cruise along the Zambezi River, spotting hippos, crocodiles, and exotic birds while sipping a drink as the sun sets. On your second day, embrace adventure with optional activities like white-water rafting, bungee jumping, or a helicopter flight over the falls for a bird’s-eye perspective. For a more relaxed pace, explore local craft markets, enjoy a spa treatment, or visit the Victoria Falls Rainforest. Evenings can be spent dining under the stars at riverside lodges, making the most of your short but unforgettable stay.

Experience the wild heart of Africa on a 2 night safari in Hwange National Park. Witness massive elephant herds, elusive leopards, lions, and hundreds of birds in untamed savannahs and woodland. Early morning and game drives bring thrilling wildlife encounters, whilst afternoons can include walking safaris, allowing you to hear about medicinal values of plants, and to see the smaller mammals and insects. Sunset drives are magical, with golden skies framing elephant silhouettes and giraffes strolling across the plains. Return to camp after dark for drinks and stories around the fire, and dinner under the star-filled skies.

Spend two nights in Matopos National Park to experience Zimbabwe’s natural beauty, wildlife, and fascinating history. Known for its dramatic granite kopjes and rolling hills, this stunning area is home to rhinos, leopards, giraffes, and diverse birdlife. Activities include guided game drives and rhino tracking on foot, learning about ancient San rock art, full day hikes and bike rides to a rural village, where you can see the effects of the Mugabe regime on local life. A UNESCO World Heritage Site, Matobo Hills is a wilderness of granite that has to be one of the most beautiful and interesting places in Zimbabwe. Massive gravity-defying granite outcrops, sculptured and shaped by the elements has created a unique, weird and wonderful “balancing rock” landscape. With more than 2000 sites of San (Bushman) rock art Matobo Hills is an area of great spiritual, cultural and historical significance.
Return road transfer to Bulawayo Airport for your flight to Johannesburg. Note that this itinerary can be shortened to suit budget and duration.

tourName: South Africa botanical holiday
generalInfo:
Welcome to South Africa, from a botanical perspective!

After recovering from the flight, you'll spend the first two days of your adventure exploring all that Cape Town has to offer: from a guided hike up Table Mountain to a city and Old Town tour as well as a visit to Kirstenbosch. You'll then be driven north to the remote Cederberg town of Clanwilliam for two days spending time on private tours of the Biedouw Valley, nature reserves and local gardens. The next three days see you taking in the sights around Nieuwoudtville such as Hantam and the local flower reserve.

Turn back to the south, you've then five days at the coast, starting with three nights in the pretty West Coast village of Paternoster for the Cape Columbine Reserve, West Coast National Park, Postberg Reserve and !Khwa tuu. You'll then head for the Cape Peninsula, stopping at the Tienie Versfeld Nature Reserve on the way, with two days in Simonstown for the Cape Point Nature Reserve, Hout Bay, Chapman's Peak and Boulder's Beach.

Leaving the coast behind, you'll head north-east and inland to the Cape Winelands, having time both in Stellenbosch and Franschhoek for visits to local reserves (Jonkershoek and Mont Rochelle) and the botanical gardens of Old Nectar and Stellenbosch University. You've time to enjoy the delights of Franschhoek on your own too. Continuing your journey south, you'll spend two nights in splendid isolation in the Kogelberg Biosphere taking one guided and one self-guided hike there. Then heading east, enjoy a night in Hermanus and the Fernkloof reserve before spending three nights in the De Hoop Nature Reserve for coastal hiking and a vulture experience.

The next two nights of your stay will take you north again to Worcester, Wellington and the town of Darling where you'll watch a spectacular one hour show at Evita se Perron and on the way will visit the Karoo Desert National Botanical Garden. You'll head back to Cape Town at the end of your journey with a day free for a second chance to climb Table Mountain or visit Kirstenbosch. Your last day is free to and prepare for your evening flight.

You'll fly out from Cape Town.

dayInfo.description: After breakfast you'll be saying goodbye to the beautiful Northern Cape. Chris will meet you for your 4 hour guided drive to the coast, south of Nieuwoudtville, to the beachfront town of Paternoster just in time for lunch at The Sandstone. After enjoying the spectacular views at The Sandstone, Chris will transfer you to Saldanha Bay Yacht club to meet, Edwin (your guide for the afternoon). From here you will embark on a 3 hour guided tour of Saldanha Reserve. Edwin is an environmentalist and nature conservationist and was the manager of SAS Saldanha Provincial Nature Reserve for 16 years before his retirement in 2016. He is a qualified facilitator and moderator as well as a photographer being involved with nature and fynbos the past 24 years and is also a registered professional guide. He also belongs to a wing of SANBI (South African National Botanical Institute) CREW (Custodians for Rare and Endangered Wildflowers). During flower season each year he organises groups to search, monitor and keep record en collect seeds of these plants in order to try to stop them going extinct. Edwin's also written an e-book on the Fynbos species flowers, and is currently busy with an e-book on the West Coast National Park flowers. After the tour, Chris will transfer you to the Strandloper Ocean Boutique Hotel, where you can check-in and get settled before dinner. The following day, you'll take a driven and walking tour of the West Coast National Park and hopefully the Postberg section (permits permitting). Overnights for this section will be at the Strandloper Ocean Boutique Hotel. Meal Inclusions: Breakfast Strandloper Ocean Boutique Hotel (3 Nights) Strandloper Ocean Boutique Hotel is a retreat, a place of calm that is completely private and secluded. It is so much more than a hotel. Strandloper is a philosophy of being in harmony with nature and blending in with the delicate beauty of the surroundings. Fall in love with this Boutique Hotel where shoes are optional and relaxation is unavoidable. Barefoot Luxury at its absolute finest! Here, heaven meets earth on the shores of the Atlantic. It is not just another place, it is another world. The 16 exquisite rooms and suites are a fusion of beach style and contemporary luxury. Organic lines, hues and textures create an overall feeling of simplicity. Each room or suite has its own courtyard or terrace with wide doors that open out onto breathtaking views of sky, sand, sea and space. Dinner this evening is booked at Wolfgat Restaurant. Wolfgat Restaurant Wolfgat offers a unique dining experience showcasing a selection of indigenous ingredients specific to this coastal location. Drawing inspiration from the surrounding landscape and its dramatic seasonal transformation, Kobus van der Merwe’s signature Strandveld food menu* comprises a series of tasting dishes presented in seven courses. Sustainable seafood, local lamb and venison, and seasonal veldkos is featured, enhanced by wild herbs, seaweeds from the local rock pools, and pickings from the garden. Some of the elements on the tasting menu take weeks of preparation, while other ingredients are handpicked on the day for the exact number of bookings received. Today, Chris will pick you up for the 1 hour drive to !Khwa ttu. You''ll be spending the day at the fascinating and beautifully designed 'embassy of the San people', !Khwa ttu. You'll go on two morning and one informative afternoon tour, exploring the botanical knowledge of the ancient San people and their traditional lifestyles while enjoying the beautiful surroundings of the veld and it’s fauna and flora. The first tour starts at 10:00 am. Enjoy wholesome, freshly prepared and locally sourced food, inspired by the San’s way of foraging, in their restaurant at lunch time. The meal is included as part of the tour. Top it all off with a drink and enjoy the breathtaking view of the West Coast... At !Khwa ttu we tell the story of human kind: The Story of the San, told in their own words... !Khwa ttu's story begins with Irene Staehelin. In 1998, the Working Group for Indigenous Minorities in Southern Africa (WIMSA) decided that the San needed assistance in unlocking potential tourism opportunities and showcasing San culture to the world. They turned to Swiss anthropologist Irene Staehelin, who agreed to help. In 1999, guided by her own vision, and inspired by heritage centres in the USA and Canada, Irene bought an 850 hectare wheat farm, on the West Coast of South Africa for the !Khwa ttu project. Irene later set up the Ubuntu Foundation in Switzerland, to help guide and support the project. !Khwa ttu opened to the public in 2006. In the following decade, inside the now restored farm buildings, it steadily developed its tourism offering and San development capabilities. Outside, the land was carefully rehabilitated and wildlife reintroduced. In September 2016 Ubuntu committed a substantial portion of the funding needed to build !Khwa ttu’s San Heritage Centre. This paved the way to fulfilling the dreams of many, and launched the next exciting stage of !Khwa ttu’s development. Meal Inclusions: Breakfast & Lunch Dinner this evening is booked at The Noisy Oyster. Again, the reception team at your hotel can arrange a transfer for you to and from the restaurant. Noisy Oyster Restaurant The Noisy Oyster is a well-loved restaurant located in the charming coastal village of Paternoster. Known for its quirky, laid-back vibe, the restaurant offers a unique and colorful dining experience with a focus on fresh, locally sourced seafood. The Noisy Oyster Restaurant: +27 (0) 22 752 2196 This morning you will embark on a full day tour of West Coast National Park. Chris will pick you up for the 40-minute drive, where you will meet your guide, Edwin, at the West Coast National Park Gate. The park is particularly well known for its bird life and for the spring flowers which occur in the months from August to September, especially in the Postberg flower reserve section of the park. Tonight, enjoy refined and contemporary West Coast Cuisine at Die Strandloper Ocean Boutique Hotel for dinner. Today, Chris will collect you at 9:00 am and drive you south to the Cape Peninsula. You'll have a chance to visit the Tienie Versfeld Nature Reserve on the way and then drive along the stunning coastal drive of Chapman's Peak and visit the villages of Llandudno, Hout Bay and Muizenberg on the way to your lodging for two nights, A Boat House in Simonstown. Meal Inclusions: Breakfast A perfectly positioned triple story guest house nested high up on the side of the mountain in the heart of the exclusive Simonkloof community of Simonstown. The guest house overlooks the yacht basin, harbour & the beautiful False Bay coastline All the rooms, which are decorated in a fresh coastal blend of blues and whites, open up onto a sheltered but sun-bleached and private deck, large enough for two sun loungers and a coffee table in most cases. You’ll love the attention to detail: really cleverly positioned reading lamps, proper coffee making equipment and a real fridge all set off with top-notch bed linen and upholstery throughout. Unlike some of the Simonstown mansions, A Boat House has it all: the views and tranquillity of the mountainside but genuinely walking distance from the town’s largely intact Victorian main street and ample parking. A Boat House is almost entirely off grid for electricity with a solar array. Today, Dominic Chadbon will meet you again and take you on a hike through the Cape Point Nature Reserve, the ragged dagger of rock at the south western-most tip of Africa where you can expect to share the beaches with penguins, ostriches, zebra and gemsbok as well as see a whole different collection of flowers from the Cape Floral Kingdom. Dinner at The Lighthouse Café After your busy day you've got a table at The Lighthouse Cafe booked. The Café has a beautiful ambience; it is an inviting space, light & airy with a French Provençal and Coastal feel which makes one feel right at home. The Café style menu is refreshingly short, although providing ample choice and variety for everyone’s taste buds, including some specials of the day. Dishes are freshly prepared by well trained staff who have a passion for food and servers are selected for both their ability to interact with customers and understanding the value of excellent service. The wine list, although small, has a very good range of wines, customers can bring their own, corkage charged. Excellent service, high standard of fresh food in a lovely setting is what The Lighthouse Café is all about! The Lighthouse Café +27 (0)21 786 9000 Cape Winelands This morning, you'll be taken on a guided drive inland from Simonstown, heading north east into the Cape Winelands. Despite the name, the Winelands are about far more than just wine: the region pours (pun intended) with creativity and history, particularly in the realm of food. The scenery is also stunningly beautiful and the range of olives, chocolate, port, brandy, cheese, fruit are world-class and form a major part of the country’s exports. There are over eight winelands towns (all very pretty and different from one another), numerous villages and in excess of 1800 wine estates. We have never met anyone who has been to all of them! You''ll start the day in Stellenbosch which is a large town with a quaint historic centre, hosting as it does one of the country's most prestigious universities. For lunch, head to Man'oushe which is situated on the effervescent Andringa Street in central Stellies, Manouche is part theatre, part restaurant - Lebanese people have been part and parcel of the South African make-up for decades, first arriving into Johannesburg in the 1940s and 50s and their cuisine and culture has had no small influence on food across the country.? Combine this with the amazingly fresh ingredients that the winelands soil can produce and you realy have a winning formula. We think that one of the best examples of the noise, fun and joie de vivre of Beirut is this place, so if you’re up for a Middle Eastern cultural taste experience, then Man’oushe is the place to visit. We would recommend asking your waiter which speciality dishes are on the menu and then go for one of them - our personal favourite is Kibbeh Nayyeh. Consider spending your afternoon exploring Stellenbosch Botanical Garden, located in the heart of Stellenbosch. (Where for us, at least, the highlights are the tree ferns and succulent collection). It's the oldest university botanical garden in South Africa, established in 1922, and is renowned for its diversity of plant species, beautiful layout, and tranquil atmosphere. You'll end the day at the historic, Oude Werf (B&B), your dinner venue for tonight (table booked for 6:00 pm) and accommodation for the next two nights. Meal Inclusions: Breakfast Oude Werf Hotel | 2 Nights Oud Werf Hotel (B&B) Situated on arguably one of the most elegant streets in the old part of Stellenbosch, the Oude Werf’s frontage displays a refined and subdued 18th century frontage to its visitors. Incredibly, this building was originally thatched and burned down twice in its history, before starting its life as a hotel in 1973 under the ownership of Gerhard Lubbe (who now owns the Montagu Country Hotel, also featured in this guide). Once inside, you’ll discover that there’s a lot more to this building than meets the eye: the current owners, the Petousis family who also own The Vineyard and The Townhouse, featured in this guide, have made a big show of the double volume reception area: resplendent with all its original carved wood accoutrements, it has been completely opened up at the rear to showcase the modern wing of the hotel – so often these extensions to beautiful old buildings simply don’t work but not so in this case. Set around a courtyard that is also home to a small pool, the hotel offers several different types of room, all totally different to each other but still in keeping with one another. You can choose from rooms in the oldest part of the building (wonderfully high ceilings, big casement windows but close to the street) or more modern rooms in the new wing (facebrick walls, big sliding windows onto decked verandas and balconies). The location of the Oude Werf is really what sets it apart – staying on a wine estate in the Winelands is fine, but being able to walk from your front door to art galleries, restaurants, coffee shops and the university just adds a whole other level of enjoyment and intrigue. Today you'll hike in the Jonkershoek Nature Reserve (Full Day) with Dominic Chadbon a.k.a. The Fynbos Guy. Chris will arrange a pick up time with you. Located just outside Stellenbosch, the reserve is known for its rugged mountains, lush fynbos, and diverse wildlife. Jonkershoek offers a variety of trails that cater to different levels of fitness and experience. Lunch is part of the hike. Meal Inclusions: Breakfast & Lunch Dinner at Delaire Graff Savour impeccably plated, creative bistro favourites with a South African touch paired with peerless wines in a breathtakingly beautiful setting. Dinner at Delaire Graff +27 (0)21 885 8160 Today sees you a short drive away in Franschhoek, perhaps the most touristy village of the Cape Winelands, but exceptionally beautiful and well kept. Here the focus is all about gastronomy at an exceptional standard and during your time here you'll sample some of the best food and wine to be found in the country. Franschhoek is packed full of things to see and do, meaning you’d need years to do them all (and that’s why many visitors come back year after year): of course the main attraction is the fact that this is gourmet capital of South Africa and so one can literally walk/stagger up and down the main street eating, drinking and then eating some more from dawn to dusk. Chris will pick you up from Oude Werf Hotel in the morning. You'll also have time to soak up the amazing scenery by going on another guided hike with Dominic through the Mont Rochelle reserve. (Full Day) Lunch is included as part of the hike. After the hike, take some time to relax and freshen up before heading out for dinner. Accommodation is at Avondrood, a guesthouse created from a historic building in this tranquil village. Meal Inclusions: Breakfast & Lunch Avondrood Guesthouse (B&B) Avondrood is a guesthouse located in one of Franschhoek’s many colonial-era farmsteads. You’ll love the huge wooden planks of the floors, the heavy beams in the ceilings and the size of the rooms behind their double sash windows. Extensively (but sensitively) renovated over the years, Justin (manager) and staff have turned the building into an eight bedroom B&B, which is four-star graded. You can make use of the pool, the jacuzzi and the lovely gardens which are sizeable for a town. It’s a delightfully tongue-in-cheek place: you’ll feel the owners’ sense of humour coming through in all sorts of ways, such as the bright red baby elephant at the poolside (who matches the sunlounger cushions!) Dinner at Le Bon Vivant Food at Le Bon Vivant is an experience. A table is booked for you. Passionate about palate perfection and impeccable presentation, chef-patron Pierre Hendricks and his team invite you on a journey of bold flavours and combinations. Pierre's profound understanding of the art of French cuisine forms the basis for Le Bon Vivant's modern interpretations of classic dishes. Dinner at Le Bon Vivant +27 (0)21 876 2717 Kogelberg Today you're going on a beautiful scenic drive for the first half of today: once you leave the Winelands, you'll travel south along the coast of False Bay, to Gordon's Bay and along Clarence Drive where if you're lucky, you'll get to see whales and their calves frolicking in the Indian Ocean waters below. You'll enter the Kogelberg Biosphere, an internationally recognised area of huge botanical and biological importance to the planet's biodiversity. Dominic will meet you to take you on a guided hike in Kogelberg Nature Reserve for the afternoon. Lunch will be part of the hike. Kogelberg is part of the Cape Floral Region, a UNESCO Work Heritage Site, and is home to over 1,880 plant species, many of which are endemic. The fynbos vegetation here is particularly diverse and includes iconic plants like proteas, ericas, and restios. Wildlife in the reserve includes various small mammals, reptiles, and birds. You might encounter animals such as klipspringers, dassies (rock hyrax), and even elusive Cape leopard. Birdwatchers will enjoy spotting species like the Cape sugarbird and orange-breasted sunbird. Meal Inclusions: Self-Catering Hamper Oudebosch Eco Cabins | 2 Nights You're staying right inside the Kogelberg Nature Reserve where Cape Nature, the organisation that manages the reserve, hosts its collection of eco-cabins. These wonderful buildings called the Oudebosch Eco Cabins have been specially designed to fit unobtrusively inside the splendidly verdent valley and additionally, are entirely constructed from sustainable materials and emitting as few emissions as possible in their design. Today you are free to hike the Oudebosch Harold Porter Trail. For breakfast, lunch and dinner you will enjoy the selection of delicious home-made foods from the self-catering basket that we have arranged for you. Meal Inclusions: Self-Catering Hamper Overberg This morning you're in for a treat: Chris will pick you up at Oudebosch and drop you at the diminutive but exceptionally diverse Fernkloof Nature Reserve in Hermanus. Here you'll be met by one of the volunteers and shown around the reserve for the morning. Lunch will be at The Wine Glass in Hermanus. The rest of the afternoon is yours to enjoy Hermanus at your leisure. Hermanus is a large coastal town, most famous for its cliff face sea frontage and the fact that the annual whale migration of Southern Right whales ends here every year. The whales (so called because in the days of whaling they were considered the ‘right’ whale to catch due to their good meat, skin and fat) normally get to our shores around August to November every year to calf. If you have the energy, we'd suggest a walk through the Walker Bay Nature Reserve on the other side of town. It's miles and miles of totally untouched beach and coastal dune forest, giving you the impression of being the last human on earth. Dinner is tonight at The Thatch House Restaurant. Accommodation for this evening is at lagoon-side The Thatch House (B&B). Meal Inclusions: Breakfast The Thatch House | 1 Night The Thatch House (B&B) Offering a refined sense of home, The Thatch House Boutique Hotel has seven large luxurious suites, in - and outdoor living areas, and lovingly-manicured sprawling gardens that are coupled with our renowned service and facilities. With relaxation a priority for guests, their team is on-hand to assist with even the smallest of arrangements. Today you'll be taken further east into the outer reaches of the Overberg, staying in the splendid De Hoop Nature Reserve. On the way, you'll be able to call in at the historic villages of Stanford and Elim and if there's time, Cape Agulhas. Or maybe even visit Grootbos Florilegium. We would recommend the De Hoop Potberg trail in the afternoon For dinner we have made a booking at The Fig Tree at De Hoop Collection for every night of your stay. Dinner is included. You've three nights staying at De Hoop Collection. Meal inclusions: Breakfast & Dinner De Hoop Collection | 3 Nights De Hoop Collection De Hoop Nature Reserve is one of the largest (340km2) natural areas managed by Cape Nature. It boasts a wealth of marine, bird, animal and rare plant species and is particularly unusual in being able to offer a large variety of endemic marine, fresh water and terrestrial animals and birds, all in one park. On top of this, it is packed with exciting adventures and activities to do inside the park. The river holds a great deal of significance in the area, starting 400km north of the coast in the mountain town of Ceres, winding its way through the Karoo until the coast and irrigating the many farms and vineyards on the way – it’s the lifeblood of the region in so many ways and is navigable by boat over 150km inland. The river teams with fish and surrounding bird life but meanders slowly through the countryside. There is hiking, bike trails, game watching, eco quad biking, whale watching among other activities all to be enjoyed in this one of a kind nature reserve. When en it’s time for lunch then we recommend you try the newly renovated offering, the Shed, also known as the Fig Tree Restaurant. Next to the main Opstal in the reserve. Enjoy a chilled glass of wine underneath the shaded terrace overlooking the De Hoop Nature Reserve. You’re staying in the Opstal Manor whilst you’re here. The Fig Tree Restaurant offers a full a la carte menu for breakfast, lunch and dinner. This remote eatery will surprise you with a sophisticated menu and flavours: the head chef is Marcia Tyobeka who brings a broad set of South African cuisines to her food, having trained across the country for many years. The staff are all locally sourced and trained from scratch in keeping with the De Hoop Reserve’s ethical HR policy. Meal Inclusions: Breakfast & Dinner This morning you'll have the opportunity to go on a guided interpretative marine walk along the pristine coastline. A walking trail exploring coastal rock pools and sandy beaches while a qualified guide points out interesting marine life forms. Also a great way to experience the Southern Right Whales in the bay between June and December. Depart an hour before low tide from the meeting tree. Times of daily low tide should be confirmed with the guides the day before. Please book at reception. In the afternoon, adventure out to the cliffs of Potberg Mountain to view endangered Cape Vultures – the Western Cape’s last surviving colony of these amazing birds. Depart from the Opstal Area in the morning (times vary according to seasons) with your guide for a scenic drive through endangered fynbos. Once at Potberg, you''ll hike (+-1 hour) up to the Vulture Deck to watch the vultures swoop and soar above. Please note that an amount of R295 per person for the interpretive marine walk and R595 per person for the vulture experience will be added to your room account and to be settled on departure. Meal Inclusions: Breakfast & Dinner Today you'll have a free day at De Hoop Collection. Enjoy your own walks along the well-marked trails through the reserve. Meal Inclusions: Breakfast & Dinner Swellendam Today you've a short drive of less than an hour from De Hoop to Swellendam, a beautiful Victorian-era town, where the streets are broad and lined with flowering jacarandas. Chris will pick you up from De Hoop. For the morning, you can either just stroll through the town, enjoying the many ateliers, plant nurseries, cafes, shops and heritage buildings. Or you might like to take a walk in the local Marloth Nature Reserve, an oasis of waterfalls, ponds and streams set in verdant, virgin forest just outside the town. It offers four main hiking trails (none too strenuous). Named after the pioneer South African botanist Rudolf Marloth who, in 1928 together with a group of Swellendam residents, petitioned the Minister of Lands and Forestry to set aside part of the mountain as a nature reserve. Over the years the reserve has been enlarged to include the remainder of the State Forest and subsequently the Swellendam hiking trail was opened. Most of the trails lead into the depths of the indigenous forest where you can explore the many rock pools and waterfalls along the way. For lunch at 12:30, enjoy excellent cuisine at Tredici. From quick bites prepared with love and attention, to a delicatessen stocked with baked goods that took as long as 36 hours to prepare. Chris will take you on a guided one and a half hour drive from Swellendam to Worcester. On the way there you'll be spending a few hours at the Karoo Desert National Botanical Garden just outside Worcester where you'll be shown round by a knowledgeable local guide, Maria Van Der Westhuizen. She is a qualified horticulturist and completed the tour guide training a few years ago. It cultivates and displays a wide variety of arid and semi-arid plants. The 154 hectare Garden lies at the foot of the Hex River Mountain range, 120 km north of Cape Town. The price for the guided tour is R120 per person which includes the garden admissions. You can pay this amount upon arrival. Please take note that they do not accept cash, only card payments. After the tour Chris will take you to your accommodation in Worcester. Meal Inclusions: Breakfast Summerhill Guest Farm | 1 Night Summerhill Guest Farm (1 night) Your accommodation for the evening is Summerhill Guest Farm (B&B). It is a working farm with many farm animals including horses, goats and bunnies. Surrounded by the majestic Brandwacht Mountains which is perfectly situated just a five minute drive from Worcester’s bustling town centre with its wine farms, restaurants and shopping mall. Meal Inclusions: Breakfast After settling in, prepare for an evening at The Hussar Grill. Your dinner reservation is at 6:30 pm. Conveniently located in the town's centre and nestled amongst the beautiful architecture of bygone eras, The Hussar Grill Worcester offers an intimate dining experience with perfectly aged succulent steaks, delectable house specialities and an award-winning wine selection. Hussar Grill: +27 (0) 23 0041 341 Wellington Today Chris will pick you up for a short drive of less than an hour from Worcester to the Limietberg Nature Reserve. Here you will embark on a thrilling Elands River trail hike, led by your guide, Justin Hawthorne. You'll enjoy a selection of delicious sandwiches for lunch that we have arranged for you. Justin is a professional mountain & nature guide. He began guiding professionally in 2014, focusing on the Fynbos, Forest as well as Succulent Karoo biomes. His primary area of guiding is within the Table Mountain National Park and areas within a day trip from Cape Town. He is currently completing his National Diploma in Nature Conservation through UNISA. He grew up in the Silvermine section of Table Mountain National Park and was exposed to the wonders of our natural environment from a young age by his parents. His father worked as a conservationist for SANParks. Justin started by becoming a volunteer guide for youth groups, before venturing into guiding as a career. After the hike, Chris will transfer you to your accommodation for the evening, Dunstone Country Estate (B&B) A table is booked at 6:30 pm for dinner at The Stone Kitchen on Dunstone Country Estate Dunstone Country Estate | 1 Night Dunstone Country Estate Dunstone Country Estate is a picturesque, guest house and boutique winery in Wellington. Situated at the foot of the Bainskloof pass, just an hour’s drive from Cape Town. Darling Today you're en route to Darling, the wonderfully named town that's become colonised in the best possible way by Pieter Dirk-Uys (a national living legend) and Darling Brew, the exceptional beer company located here. After a delicious breakfast at Dunstone Country Estate, Chris will pick you up at 10:00 am for a one hour drive to Darling. At 12:00 pm, get a revised history lesson from South Africa's most famous white woman, Evita Bezuidenhout, as she presents her sidesplitting, satirical stand-up Tannie Evita Praat Kaktus (Auntie Evita Talks Cactus) at her famed and beloved theatre, Evita se Perron, in Darling. For over 20 years, author, actor and activist Pieter-Dirk Uys has been enduring high-heels and extra long lashes to bring his most famous character to life. As a matron of political incorrectness, an honorary member of the ANC and a self-declared former ambassadress of a fictitious Bantustan called Bapetikosweti, Evita Bezuidenhout spends her time in the little town of Darling, 85km from Cape Town, performing at Evita se Perron throughout the year. Bezuidenhout made her debut in 1982, and has since gained international acclaim for performances that poked fun, first, at the ridiculous laws under Apartheid, and then, at the leaders of the new, democratic South Africa. She has dined with Nelson Mandela, been kissed on the cheek by Archbishop Desmond Tutu and even received the Women’s International Centre’s 2000 Living Legacy Award in San Diego – an honour received by the likes of Hillary Clinton and Mother Theresa. She is, indeed, a national treasure, giving us reason to laugh at our typically sobering politics and history. After this spectacular one hour show, a table is booked for you 1:30 pm for lunch at Ciao Darling, a family restaurant, trattoria and pizzeria situated in the heart of Darling. Enjoy their freshly home-made pasta and array of wood fired pizzas before the two hour scenic journey back to Cape Town in the afternoon. Upon arrival in Cape Town, Chis will take you to Parker Cottage again, your accommodation for the next three nights. You'll have the rest of the afternoon to settle in, rest and recuperate. Take a Taxi to the V&A Waterfront later. For dinner, you have the freedom to choose from the myriad of restaurants at the V&A Waterfront. Whether you're in the mood for local delicacies, international cuisine, or something in between, the staff at Parker Cottage will be delighted to recommend the perfect dining spot to suit your preferences. Meal Inclusions: Breakfast Cape Town: 16th to 17th September, 2024 16 September 2024 Today you'll be hiking Disa Gorge with Table Mountain hiking guide, Nick Ashby. Chris will meet you at Parker Cottage at 9am to take you to the meeting point. Your guide, Nick Ashby Nick is a fully qualified and registered guide. It wasn't his first job, though. He worked as an actor for ten years, having studied drama at UCT in Cape Town. When both him and his wife decided to take a year off acting to travel, it turned into seven. During that time they became English teachers. They've taught in Egypt, Russia, and then Taiwan. They became parents in the USA, and studied Mandarin. They hiked and trekked wherever they went. Since back in South Africa in 2005, Nick has published a novel, taught some more, as well as kept guiding on his old favorite, Table Mountain, first explored as a boy scout, and other hiking trails around the Cape. This afternoon, you are spending some time again with Dominic Chadbon on Signal Hill. For dinner, you have the freedom again to choose from the myriad of restaurants at the V&A Waterfront. Whether you're in the mood for local delicacies, international cuisine, or something in between, the staff at Parker Cottage will be delighted to recommend the perfect dining spot to suit your preferences. Meal Inclusions: Breakfast Going Home 17 September 2024 You'll have a leisurely start to the last day of your holiday with breakfast at Parker Cottage. The morning is yours to enjoy at your own pace. Take this opportunity to do some last-minute shopping for souvenirs or explore any corners of Cape Town you haven't yet visited. In the afternoon, you can soak in the final moments of your Cape Town adventure, perhaps with a visit to a local market, a stroll along the V&A Waterfront, or simply relaxing at a cafe with a view of Table Mountain. At 8:00 pm, Chris will arrive to transfer you to Cape Town International Airport. There, you'll board KLM0598 flight at 23:15 pm for your journey home. Safe travels until we meet again!

tourName: South Africa coastal adventure holiday
generalInfo:
Buckle up and get ready for a 10-day / 9-night adventure like no other in one of the most stunning countries in the world! From hiking along breath-taking coastlines to diving into crystal-clear waters and basking in the sun on pristine white sandy beaches, this South African tour has it all.

We'll start your journey in the vibrant city of Cape Town, where we'll whisk you away to the charming Tamboerskloof suburb. Spend two cozy nights at Parker Cottage before exploring the city's many attractions on an open-top City Sightseeing bus, with over 30 stops to choose from!

Next up, prepare for an unforgettable hiking adventure along the awe-inspiring Tsitsikamma coast on the Dolphin Trail. Stay in luxurious lodges that offer delicious food and stunning views of the Indian Ocean. And don't worry about carrying heavy backpacks - we'll take care of transporting your luggage for you! Hike suspension bridges, ridges, and rocky paths while spotting whales and dolphins along the way.

But the adventure doesn't end there! You'll overnight in Johannesburg before finishing your epic journey in style at Thonga Beach Lodge, where you'll spend 3 nights. Here can choose to take guided walks through the forest, scuba dive or snorkel in crystal-clear waters, or simply lounge on the beach and soak up the sun.

Are you ready to make unforgettable memories and experience the ultimate combination of scuba diving, sightseeing and slackpacking? Let's dive in!

dayInfo.description: Ready for an unforgettable adventure? Your first stop is the vibrant and beautiful Cape Town! As soon as you land at Cape Town International Airport, we'll take you straight to Parker Cottage (B&B), a cozy and eco-friendly guesthouse located in the charming Tamboerskloof suburb. Get ready to immerse yourself in the heart of the city, as you spend the next two nights in the vibrant City Bowl, an area bursting with character and charm. To make the most of your time in the "Mother City," we recommend exploring it on an open-top City Sightseeing bus. With over 30 stops and 50 top attractions, you can hop-on and hop-off as much as you want! See the city's iconic landmarks like Table Mountain and the V&A Waterfront, or venture off the beaten path to discover hidden gems and local hotspots. Whether you're a first-time visitor or a seasoned traveler, Cape Town is sure to captivate your heart and leave you wanting more. Get ready for an adventure-packed journey that's as thrilling as it is beautiful!

On day 3, get ready to experience the ultimate hiking adventure on the Dolphin Trail! You'll explore the stunning Tsitsikamma coast for three nights, staying in luxurious lodges with incredible views of the Indian Ocean and mouth-watering meals to fuel your journey. The best part? No heavy backpacks weighing you down - your luggage will be transported by vehicle to your overnight stops. All you need to bring is a light day pack and your camera to capture the unforgettable views! After a morning flight from Cape Town to George, you'll meet your expert Dolphin Trail guide and head to one of the charming Dolphin Trail Chalets for the night. This is the perfect opportunity to relax and rejuvenate, surrounded by the beauty of nature and the sound of the crashing waves. Get ready to make memories that will last a lifetime on this thrilling and unforgettable hiking adventure!

Rise and shine on Day 4 with a refreshing morning swim or some bird watching to kick things off! Then, get ready to hit the hiking trails and take in some seriously breathtaking views. Cross the mighty Storms River on a suspension bridge and wind your way along rocky paths and ridges until you reach an epic lookout point with sweeping vistas of the coast all the way to Plettenberg Bay. And keep your eyes peeled for some whale and dolphin sightings along the way! After a day of adventure and exploration, it's time to unwind and let loose with a sunset Quad Bike Tour at the amazing Misty Mountain Lodge. After an exhilarating ride, treat yourself to a scrumptious 3-course dinner that'll leave you feeling satisfied and totally content. Day 4 is all about taking in the best of nature, indulging in some thrilling activities, and making unforgettable memories.

Day 5 is a real treat, as you'll get to explore the stunning coastal scenery at sea level - be sure to pack your snorkelling gear! After a challenging uphill climb, you'll be treated to a well-deserved picnic lunch before embarking on a leisurely 3km forest walk to The Fernery. And what better way to unwind after an exhilarating day than to soak in a jacuzzi or sauna? It's the perfect end to a truly fantastic adventure!

Start your day with breakfast at The Fernery. Afterward, head to Port Elizabeth Airport for a scenic ride. Fly to Johannesburg and stay at The Peech Hotel in Melrose, a stylish and eco-friendly boutique hotel. Enjoy dinner at the hotel's restaurant, then unwind in your cozy Classic Room for a restful night’s sleep.

You’re back in the air with a flight to the Kwa-Zulu Natal town of Richards Bay today, where pick up your rental vehicle and make your way to your lodging for the next three nights at the sensational Thonga Beach Lodge. Head out on foot on a guided walk through the forest where you’ll have the opportunity to see some of the multitude of bird, plant, spider and butterfly species from the area. Enjoy scuba diving and snorkelling, as well as kayaking on Lake Sibaya … or just laze the day away soaking up the sun on the unspoiled white sandy beach.

This is your last day in South Africa. You’ll drive from Thonga Beach Lodge to Durban, where you’ll fly out from Durban International Airport today with what we hope are some outstanding memories to hold onto until we see you again!

tourName: South Africa culture and township stay
generalInfo:
Embark on a captivating 10-day journey through South Africa's vibrant cities and stunning landscapes. This tour offers a profound exploration of the country's rich history, diverse cultures, and breathtaking natural beauty.

Begin your adventure in Johannesburg, the pulsating heart of South Africa, where you'll spend the first two nights. Here, delve into the country's poignant apartheid history and explore local wildlife within the tranquillity of the surrounding nature reserves.

Next, fly to Cape Town, often referred to as the Mother City, for a seven-night stay that promises a blend of majestic natural wonders and urban exploration. Marvel at the iconic Table Mountain with a cable car ride to its summit, offering panoramic views of the city and beyond. Experience the historical significance of Robben Island, where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned, and explore the cultural heritage of the Cape Peninsula, including visits to the vibrant districts of Bo-Kaap and District Six.

Your tour also takes you on a sensory journey through the renowned Cape Winelands, where you'll taste world-class wines and learn about the pioneering efforts of black vintners in the region. A visit to the coastal enclave of Muizenberg allows for an exhilarating surfing session, while a day in Langa offers a deep dive into the township's community and arts scene.

The adventure concludes with an insightful exploration of the San culture at !Khwa ttu, providing a poignant reflection on the resilience and rich traditions of South Africa’s indigenous people.

Throughout this journey, witness the dynamic contrasts between urban vitality and serene landscapes, connect with local communities, and savour the diverse flavours of South African cuisine. This tour is not just a trip; it's an immersive experience into the soul of South Africa.

dayInfo.description: South Africa's vibrant "City of Gold" awaits! Touch down in Johannesburg and meet your friendly Camissa Tours guide, ready to whisk you away on a scenic 30-minute transfer to Thaba Eco Hotel. Nestled within the Klipriviersberg Reserve, this haven offers a unique blend of luxury and nature. Unwind in your plush Superior King Suite after 2 pm, where breathtaking reserve views greet you. The afternoon is yours to explore! Lace up your boots and hike alongside zebras and antelope on well-marked trails, or delve deeper into Johannesburg's energy with a City Sightseeing bus tour. As the sun dips below the horizon, indulge in a delectable dinner at the hotel restaurant. Their menu showcases South African culinary traditions with a contemporary twist. Savor succulent springbok carpaccio or a comforting vegetarian bobotie, all amidst the restaurant's elegant ambiance. Panoramic views of the reserve add a touch of magic to your dining experience. Drift off to sleep under the vast African sky in your luxurious haven. This first night sets the stage for an unforgettable Johannesburg adventure, filled with discovery and relaxation.

Your day begins with a scenic 9:00 AM transfer from Thaba Eco Hotel to the Cradle of Humankind, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. This remarkable area boasts a wealth of fossils, offering a glimpse into the fascinating story of humankind. Your exploration starts at Maropeng, the official visitor center. Here, interactive exhibits bring the formation of Earth and the incredible saga of human evolution over millions of years vividly to life. The center's unique design, resembling an ancient burial mound, immerses you in the past, making every step an engaging journey of discovery. Next, delve deeper into history at the Malapa Museum, home to the captivating fossils of Australopithecus sediba – a key species in understanding human evolution. Nestled amidst the Cradle's natural beauty, the museum provides a window into the lives of our ancestors. From 12:30 PM to 2:00 PM, savor a delectable lunch at The Cradle Boutique Hotel. Surrounded by the serenity of this significant archaeological landscape, the atmosphere is as enriching as the food itself. Reflect on the morning's discoveries as you enjoy a delicious meal. The afternoon continues with a short transfer to the NIROX Sculpture Park. This open-air haven seamlessly blends art and nature, showcasing a collection of impressive sculptures by international artists set amidst lush gardens. From 2:30 PM to 4:30 PM, wander through the grounds and marvel at the art installations thoughtfully integrated with the natural environment, creating a tranquil and inspiring experience. Following a day filled with profound history and contemporary culture, return to Thaba Eco Hotel by 5:30 PM. Conclude your day with another delightful dinner at the hotel, allowing you to unwind and reflect under the expansive South African sky. This perfect blend of history, nature, and culinary delights perfectly captures the essence of your South African adventure.

Camissa Tours will collect you from Thaba Eco Hotel at 8:45 AM for a journey into Soweto's rich history and culture. Your enlightening tour kicks off at 9:00 AM, delving into key sites of the anti-apartheid struggle. The iconic Apartheid Museum becomes your first stop. Here, powerful exhibits vividly recount the story of apartheid, offering a profound understanding of South Africa's path to freedom. Following the museum's emotional impact, take a reflective walk at 11:30 AM from the Hector Pieterson Museum to Mandela House on Vilakazi Street. This walk weaves through historically significant locations, capturing the spirit and resilience of the Soweto community during the struggle. Indulge in authentic township cuisine at 12:00 PM with lunch at Sakhumzi Restaurant on the famous Vilakazi Street. Savor traditional dishes like umngqusho (samp and beans) and mogodu (tripe) in this lively setting, experiencing Soweto's warm hospitality firsthand. The afternoon unfolds with a transfer to the Credo Mutwa Cultural Village at 1:30 PM. From 2:00 PM to 4:00 PM, explore this open-air museum, designed by renowned artist and healer Credo Mutwa. A collection of sculptures and buildings reflects African art, culture, and folklore, fostering a deeper appreciation for the continent's heritage. Check into your Deluxe Double Room at Ekuthuleni Guest House at 4:00 PM, experiencing Soweto's charm and hospitality in a comfortable, intimate setting. In the evening, unwind at Café Bohemia at 8:00 PM. This local gem boasts a cozy, artistic atmosphere and a diverse menu featuring South African and global flavors, perfect for a relaxed evening meal. Reflect on your day's rich historical and cultural tapestry before settling in for a restful night at Ekuthuleni Guest House, where your return transfer awaits.

An early morning transfer takes you from Ekuthuleni Guest House to Johannesburg's O.R. Tambo International Airport. Soar through the skies and upon arrival in Cape Town, a friendly Camissa Tours representative will greet you at Cape Town International Airport, ensuring a smooth transition to your next adventure. Your haven in Cape Town awaits – the legendary Parker Cottage. Built in 1895 by John Parker, Cape Town's first mayor, this charming establishment boasts a history as rich and diverse as the city itself. Originally two separate houses – one for John Parker and his family, the other for his in-laws – it embodies his life story, a testament to determination and vision. From arriving in Cape Town at 15 with little to his name, he became a prominent architect and eventually, the city's mayor. Today, Parker Cottage is a luxurious 10-bedroom residence, sensitively renovated to retain its original charm while offering all the modern amenities expected of a four-star establishment. This dedication extends to sustainability and ethical responsibility, with the establishment operating completely off-grid for water, electricity, and heating/cooling, and holding Fair Trade Accreditation. After settling into your deluxe room, join Camissa Tours for a thrilling ride on the Table Mountain Cableway from 9:00 AM to 11:30 AM. Ascend to the summit in a revolving cable car, marveling at the breathtaking 360-degree views of Cape Town, the ocean, and the surrounding landscapes.
