Embrace the rhythm of long watches, open-ocean wildlife encounters, and the satisfaction of a real ocean crossing

Duration: 3 weeks (including time on St Helena)
A genuine adventure of a lifetime — the kind of voyage few sailors ever experience.

dayInfo.description: St Helena (Island Exploration) Arrival & check-in at your island B&B (breakfast included) Optional island highlights: Visit Jonathan, the world’s oldest living land animal (over 190 years old!) Explore Napoleon’s House at Longwood and his final resting place Walk coastal trails, visit the coffee plantation, and enjoy snorkelling/diving in warm waters Meet the famously warm and welcoming St Helenians Evenings to enjoy local restaurants and the relaxed pace of island life
Departure from St Helena Final provisioning and passage planning Set sail westward into the vast South Atlantic Ocean Establish watch systems and settle into life at sea

7–19 – South Atlantic Ocean Crossing 13 days at sea (weather dependent) Long-haul bluewater sailing: Atlantic swells, big skies, and dynamic conditions Sail training focus: Celestial navigation practice under star-filled skies Weather routing, trimming and reefing for heavy seas Offshore routines: night watches, helming, log-keeping Wildlife encounters: albatross, flying fish, dolphins — sometimes even whales in the deep ocean

Landfall in South Africa Approach the dramatic coastline of the Western Cape Navigate into Table Bay with Table Mountain rising ahead — one of the world’s most iconic landfalls Arrival into Royal Cape Yacht Club, Cape Town Skipper’s debrief and logbook sign-offs
Cape Town Trip ends after breakfast onboard Time to explore Cape Town’s highlights: the V&A Waterfront, Robben Island, or a celebratory wine tour in Stellenbosch

tourName: The Garden Route and beyond, South Africa
generalInfo:
The Garden Route, which traverses the south coast of South Africa from Cape Town to Addo, is arguably one of the most splendid road trips you can do anywhere on the planet. Whilst it can in theory be driven in a day (under 12 hours, as it's around 1 000km long), in reality the massive variety of biome, the number of experiences and places along the route mean that an absolute minimum is really five days.

So we've deliberately kept the pace of this journey sedate to allow you to fully experience the unique identity of each place along the route: the Garden Route is often touted as a 'drive along the N2' (that's the name of the main highway that connects the larger towns) and whilst this is to an extent true, getting off the highway and getting to the more remote locations makes this into a truly magical trip.

This trip is 100% ethical; every supplier has made a commitment - and has been independently audited in the fulfillment of that commitment - to placing people and planet first in every aspect of their business practice. Rest assured then that everything you will see and do on this trip makes a positive impact on the places and people you visit, not the opposite. This is a self-drive route but we can just as easily make this into a guided and chauffered route if you like. Contact us for a price.

tourName: Three Reserve safari in South Africa
placesVisited: Wild Rivers Private Nature Reserve, bush senses experience, Balule Reserve, game drive with rangers, bush walks, Timbavati Game Reserve
generalInfo:
Immerse yourself in the African bush and enjoy spotting big game on this great-value South African safari. Look out for the Big Five and enjoy birding, too, in three different game reserves in the Greater Kruger Park region, while also enjoying plenty of down time to just sit back, chill out and soak up the sights and sounds of the bush landscape.

Accommodation is in excellent games lodges in the Wild Rivers Nature Reserve, Klaserie Game Reserve and Thornybush Game Reserve , with all meals included. This trip begins and ends at Hoedspruit Airport and the cost includes all transfers and accommodation, as well as two fully guided game drives each day. Departures are throughout the year.

dayInfo.description: Your safari begins at Hoedspruit Airport (HDS) were you will be met by on arrival by a member of our team and transferred to Rukiya Safari Camp just 25 mins away. Hoedspruit's Eastgate Airport is the established gateway to the heartland of South Africas wildlife game viewing reserves and has several daytime flights arriving each day from Johannesburg, that are scheduled to assist international visitors to easily connect with Hoedspruit.. Many of our guests prefer us to arrange for their internal flight from Johannesburg to Hoedspruit (50 mins), or alternately for a scenic road transfer (approx 7 hours) which takes the hassle out of arranging the final leg of your journey and is a service that we offer our guests at cost price. Whichever transfer you prefer you will arrive at Rukiya Safari Camp in time to settle in and rest and relax. Rukiya is a small luxury tented camp within the Wild Rivers Reserve and is a key area for our leopard research team. The camp nestles along the banks of the Blyde River among age old tress, a truly stunning location. Later in the day, before the sun sets we’ll take a short stroll along the river bank and enjoy a sundowner, returning to the lodge for dinner.

You are woken with an invigorating cup of coffee before setting off on a morning game drive, which will take you through the Wild Rivers Reserve and into the adjacent Balule Reserve (part of the Greater Kruger Park) where you will be able to enjoy your first big five game drive as well as a bush breakfast. Lunch is followed by time to relax and enjoy the views from your private deck with river views, before your afternoon game drive in the Wild Rivers Reserve, which returns home for a sumptuous dinner. On your first full day on safari we will include our unique bush senses experience. This is an activity that we have developed over many years and has proven to be very popular with our safari guests. In a fun way it encourages you to use all of your senses when in the bush. Not just sight, but also smell, hearing and touch. Some of our senses are dulled by modern living, but this simple and fun exercise quickly hones one’s bush senses, ideal preparation for any safari. We also encourage our guests to download our leopard research App and become a citizen scientist by using the App while on game drive to help monitor Leopard movement. Territorial behaviour changes almost on a daily basis and is dependent on many factors, making this a fascinating and fun exercise and rightfully invites you to feel and become part of the Ingwe team should you wish.

An early morning game drive will again take you through the Wild Rivers Reserve and into the adjacent Balule Reserve, breakfast will be served in the bush before return to Rukiya. There will be time to rest and relax and enjoy lunch, and when the heat of the day has faded a little, you may join our rangers learning to track leopards and other predators within the reserve, where our Leopard researchers are monitoring the resident leopard population. Return to camp for drinks and dinner.

After your morning game drive you will transfer to the Klaserie Reserve (approximately 2 hours) arriving in time for a late lunch. Klaserie is another key location for our Leopard Research project. Your afternoon Game drive will leave the lodge at around 15:30 heading out into the reserve. Our private traversing area of Klaserie offers both wonderful game viewing and often exclusive access making this a fantastic location to view wildlife. Sundowners will be served while watching the sunset after which, as darkness falls, you will take a leisurely drive back to your lodge looking out for all the nocturnal happenings and returning in time for drinks before dinner.

No two days are the same on safari where nature calls the tunes, making each day a fresh adventure. Across the next two days you can enjoy morning and afternoon game drives traversing pristine big five country. But remember game viewing doesn't necessarily stop when you are back at your lodge. Animals will often walk by, so keep your cameras close as you never know who will appear, from Elephants, Zebra, Wildebeest and Giraffe to name but a few. As ever breakfast, lunch and dinner together with snacks while on game drive are included.

After breakfast we will transfer to the near by Thorybush Game Reserve, famed for its exceptional game viewing and a favoured location for movie stars and the rich and famous, providing a lovely sedate bush atmosphere, with personal and friendly service. Even on bush roads it takes only 55 mins to transfer to Thornybush so you will have plenty of time to settle in and relax before afternoon high tea and game drive. Again returning to your lodge for dinner.

Over the next two days you can enjoy game drive in the company of our lodge's rangers and trackers, who not only aim to find you animals, but will also introduce you to the wealth of flora, fauna, bird life and cultural heritage of the region. Morning's game drive will leave at dawn and the afternoon drive will leave at around 15:30. Our aim on your final day is to focus on any particular wishes you might have. That may be an animal or bird that you haven't yet seen, or perhaps returning to that herd of Elephant just to sit and enjoy being in their company.

Time permitting, an early morning game drive before breakfast, hoping to get those final photographs or enjoy the last sights and sounds that will stay in your memory for ever. After breakfast you will transfer through the reserve to Hoedspruit Airport (approximately 30 mins) for your homeward flights.

tourName: Underwater photography holiday in South Africa
generalInfo:
Take a deep dive into the vibrant world of marine image-making on South Africa’s east coast. This 28-day intensive program, offered by Africa Media, is set along the Indian Ocean at the edge of the Aliwal Shoal Marine Protected Area, a global hotspot for marine biodiversity. Designed for aspiring and emerging underwater photographers, the program blends hands-on dive experience with expert instruction, conservation ethics, and creative development.

From capturing reef macro scenes to filming sharks in the blue, each day balances structured lessons with immersive dive sessions to build both technical mastery and artistic voice. Taught by rotating instructors from Africa Media’s expert team, the program emphasizes responsible wildlife storytelling, sustainability, and the power of media to advocate for marine conservation.

Whether you're entering the field fresh or seeking to build a compelling portfolio, this small-group lead program provides the guidance, gear, and environment to explore the depths–both literal and creative!

HIGHLIGHTS:

World-Class Dive Location: Explore the Aliwal Shoal Marine Protected Area—home to over 1,200 species of marine life including turtles, rays, reef sharks, and vibrant coral systems.

Intensive Dive-Based Training: Complete 18 dive sessions tailored to macro, wide-angle, and artistic underwater photography or videography.

All Equipment Provided: DSLR cameras, underwater housings, strobes, lights, and full SCUBA equipment are included for the duration of the program.

Professional Instruction & Mentorship: Learn from professional underwater photographers and filmmakers committed to conservation and ethical wildlife storytelling.

Ethical Marine Interaction: Strict adherence to no-touch, low-impact dive principles and reef-safe practices ensure your photography contributes to marine preservation.

Final Portfolio Showcase: End the program with a curated presentation of your best work during a celebratory review session with instructors and peers.

dayInfo.description: Land at Durban International and transfer to your self-catering accommodation in Scottburgh. Get to know your instructors and peers while learning the basics of DSLR camera housing systems, gear maintenance, and ocean safety. Introductory lectures on composition, exposure, and marine conservation ethics lay the foundation for the month.

Begin your underwater journey in pools and protected areas, building strong fundamentals in buoyancy and camera handling. Practice macro photography techniques using strobes, soft lighting, and careful framing with marine life and staged objects. Daily reviews help reinforce learning.

Enter the marine reserve for your first open water macro dives. Photograph nudibranchs, coral textures, and crustaceans while learning to work with ambient light and flash photography. Post-dive sessions focus on creative critique and image selection.

Shift to wide-angle shooting, with shark dives and free-diving snorkel sessions. Learn to manage movement, subject distance, and environmental lighting while working with large marine subjects like blacktip sharks and rays. Editing workshops begin with Adobe Lightroom and Premiere Pro.

Develop storytelling through stylized underwater shoots using models and props. Learn to direct a subject, build visual concepts, and refine shots through in-depth editing tutorials. Explore nearby rock pools for low-impact, high-impact photo opportunities.
Dives and sessions continue throughout the month with increasing complexity and creative direction.

tourName: Victoria Falls to Johannesburg overland tour
generalInfo: Experience the incredible diversity of Southern Africa - from the abundant wildlife of the Okavango Delta, Etosha and Addo National Park, to the breathtaking scenery of the Namib Desert, Fish River Canyon and the Drakensburg Mountains. Try your hand at white water rafting, bungy jumping, quad biking & dune sledding at one of the adrenaline havens, Victoria Falls, Swakopmund or Cape Town. This truly is a trip to stun the senses. Note: This is one of our Overland Adventures which are run using one of our specialist famous yellow overland expedition trucks. Trips are run on a participatory basis – you’ll be involved in the day to day running of the trip and have fun taking turns helping to shop and cook for the group. Expect to sometimes get dusty and dishevelled and not to be able to have hot showers every night. Groups of up to 24 people are led by our crew of two. Please note that the accommodation on this trip is predominantly camping, though there may be opportunities to upgrade this locally where rooms are available. Please see the trip inclusions for an approximate percentage of camping and room nights. Our Overland Adventures provide once in a life time experiences and whilst some safari activities may be included in the itinerary, or be available to book locally, this should not be considered a traditional safari holiday, though we consider that part of the fun!!

dayInfo.description: Victoria Falls Your trip starts with a full day in Victoria Falls. For some, Mosi oa Tunya - The Smoke That Thunders, is the highlight of their African safari. From the main road, in the bush 20kms away, a cloud of mist and spray can be seen against the blue sky. As you get closer, a low rumble like thunder can be heard. When you arrive it is a surprise to discover the enormity of Victoria Falls. One mile wide and hurling over 5 million cubic metres of water a minute into the Zambezi Gorge this sight is breath taking at any time of year. The water levels vary hugely depending on the time of year, but it is always an amazing spectacle - in fact it can actually be better when there is a little less water, as there is less spray blocking the falls from view. The Gorge below the falls is also the setting for one of the most adrenaline fuelled grade 5 white water rafting rivers in the world. But there is also plenty to do here for the less active too. Why not take a day trip over the Victoria Falls bridge to view the falls from Zambia, take the Flight of Angels - a great way to get a birds eye view of the falls in a microlight or helicopter, enjoy a civilised afternoon tea at the Victoria Falls Hotel, join a Sunset Boat Cruise or a more sedate Canoe trip. For those who want to make the most of the adrenaline activities, get your fix with the Gorge Swing, Abseil or 'enjoy' one of the highest commercial Bungee Jumps in the world.

Chobe, Salt Pans & Okavango Delta We depart Victoria Falls and also leave Zimbabwe, crossing into Botswana where we spend the night at Kasane, on the outskirts of the Chobe National Park - famous for its hordes of Elephants, as well as an abundance of other wildlife. You will have a chance to spend the afternoon on an included boat cruise on the Chobe River - a less intrusive way to view game and wildlife - as well as the Namibian frontier across the river. There is also time to take an optional game safari into the park if you wish. We then head south into the Kalahari Basin - known for its dry, desolate and expansive plains. On our way we will pass the Nata Bird Sanctuary, and the Makgadikgadi Salt Pans, one of the largest salt flats in the world. After we arrive in Maun, you will have an opportunity to leave the truck to venture into the Okavango Delta. Local poler guides will navigate the extensive waterways using canoes similar to their traditional Mokoro's (dug out canoes). This is a great experience - and a great way to have a chance of seeing some of elusive wildlife of this unique desert oasis. After the mokoro trip on the water, you will have a number of opportunities to go on game walks with rangers - giving you the chance to see elephant, crocodile and hippo up close and personal. The Okavango Delta is one of the world's largest inland waterways and its calming serenity will leave those who experience it feeling supremely relaxed. There is also the opportunity to experience the heights of African adventure travel too

Maun to Etosha Travelling west we enter Namibia and continue toward Etosha National Park - recognised as one of the worlds greatest wildlife viewing areas. The semi desert is quite a contrast to the more fertile terrain we have been used to, and the desert elephants that make their home here are a famous highlight. The night sky ablaze with shooting stars and the warm glow of our campfire makes for unforgettable camping experiences. Besides game drives done on our truck, we can also game watch by night at one of the floodlit water holes where we may well spot Rhino, Elephant and Giraffe among a host of other wildlife.

Etosha to Spitzkoppe From Etosha we drive to the Brandberg Mountains in Demaraland, a huge granite outcrop and home to the famous White Lady rock painting, an important and striking piece of Damara and Bushman rock art. We will aim to make a bush camp amidst the stunning Spitzkoppe Rock formations. Known as the Matterhorn of Namibia - the Spitzkoppe is part of the Erongo Mt range and was formed over 100 million years ago after the collapse of a gigantic volcano. The scenery is striking from every angle - even more stunning as the granite massifs turn red at sunset.

Spitzkoppe to Swakopmund Our next stop is the world famous Cape Cross Seal Colony, where the sight of thousands of these mammals, as well as their accompanying pungent odour is remembered by all! The Cool Atlantic Ocean and the prominent Benguela current provide a perfect location for feeding and breeding for the Cape Fur Seal. We will then drive down the Skeleton Coast, where desert sand dunes come right to the sea, and several shipwrecks can be seen still on the beaches. For the next two days, our Africa overland trip will be based in Swakopmund - Namibia's adventure gateway. You can choose between a variety of activities and excursions here

Sossusvlei, Deadvlei & Fish River Canyon A one day drive takes us to the Namib-Naukluft Park, a vast expanse of desert which contains some of the highest sand dunes in the world. At Sossusvlei we stop and explore this spectacular area and red dunes, including the iconic Dune 45, which we climb before breakfast one morning. We can also visit the stunning scenery of Deadvlei, where 800 year old black preserved trees stand out in huge contrast to the orange sands and blue sky behind them. Continuing south we enter the semi-desert, and wide-open countryside of cattle ranching until we arrive at one of Africa's most sensational natural features, Fish River Canyon. We stop here for a couple of hours to take in the awesome scenery. We'll then continue and cross the border into South Africa and also cross the Orange River - a rich source of diamonds.

Orange River to Stellenbosch We travel south through the Cederburg Wilderness Area, an area of rugged valleys and peaks before getting to winelands and farms of Stellenbosch. We'll spend a night here and you can take a very educational (and enjoyable!) guided tour around some of the wineries in the region, tasting as you go.

Stellenbosch to Cape Town Our journey to Cape Town finishes with a short drive from Stellenbosch into the city, where we stay in a backpacker hostel. There is plenty to do in and around Cape Town, from climbing up Table Mountain to abseiling down it, diving with sharks (either in ocean cages - or at the Two Oceans Aquarium), a tour to Robben Island or head out on the town to one of the many hot spots that Cape Town has to offer.
Cape Town You have a couple of free days in Cape Town to enjoy the sights and do any optional tours or day trips.

Cape Town to Little Karoo We depart from Cape Town taking a leisurely drive along the coastal roads to the Cape of Good Hope, a rocky headland at the southern end of the Cape peninsula. Here you have a chance to walk up to the upper lighthouse, or take a ride on the Flying Dutchman Funicular for some spectacular views. After visiting the Cape we follow the coastline on to our next stop. We overnight in Hermanus/Gansbaai and the next day there are a number of marine options - Whale watching, Shark Cave Diving and Dyer Island Nature Reserve. From here we will head for the most southern tip of Africa at Cape Agulhas - which is the dividing line between the warm Indian Ocean and the cooler Atlantic Ocean. The seas around Cape Agulhas are very treacherous and have caused numerous shipwrecks, to help reduce fatalities the Cape Agulhas Lighthouse was built in 1848 and is the 2nd oldest working lighthouse in South Africa. From August to December Southern Right and Humpback Whales may be spotted along the coast - as they feed in the nutrient rich waters off the southern coast. From Cape Agulhas we pass through the Outeniqua Mountains to the Little Karoo - we will visit an Ostrich farm to learn more about the worlds largest bird. The Ostrich has been around for 8 million years and a feather was actually discovered in King Tutankhamun's tomb in Egypt. 97% of the world's population of Ostriches lives in the Karoo. We will also explore Cango Calcite Caves recognised as one of the world's finest network of Calcite caves. The bizarre formations of Stalagmites and Stalactites represent over a million years of slow formation.

Little Karoo to Addo National Park We spend two days winding our way along South Africa's famous Garden Route where there is a wealth of things to see and do. We travel through the popular resort of Knysna, located on a tranquil lagoon that is protected from the sea by two enormous cliffs known as 'the heads'. We visit the Tsitsikamma Forest, where you will be able to hike along the coast and view the crashing waves at the mouth of the scenic Storms River, and maybe spot dolphins and whales in the ocean. Optional excursions in this region include mountain biking, black water tubing, and the mother of all bungee jumps at Bloakrans Bridge - the highest jump in the world at 216 metres. From the Garden Route we continue along the coast and in the summer months (October to March) there will be an opportunity to stop at one of the beaches we pass before we head inland to Addo Elephant National Park which has recently been extended to include part of the coast and is now home to the BIG 7 - lion, rhino, elephant, leopard, buffalo, whale and shark! On our game drive we hope to spot some of the many elephant that the park is famous for, which are the most southerly population in Africa.

Addo National Park to Lesotho We then drive to the beautiful, rugged and remote Wild Coast to the quaint little seaside village of Cintsa. Situated on the banks of the Cintsa River and estuary - Cintsa offers a haven in a tranquil setting, surrounded by lush indigenous forest and thicket, and an amazing bird life. You will have a fee day to enjoy the unspoiled stretches of white sandy beaches, take a canoe ride up the river, many hikes in the area, horse riding and so much more. We will then make our way towards the mountain Kingdom of Lesotho overnighting on route.

Lesotho to Royal Natal National Park Lesotho, often referred to as 'the kingdom in the sky'. This little country is completely surrounded by South Africa and is covered by mountains from 1000m to 3000m high. The scenery here is tremendous and the mountain air crisp and fresh. Here we will see Lesotho's horsemen dressed in their blankets and gumboots trotting around the hillsides. We spend a couple of nights at Malealea Lodge, Lesotho's most famous countryside retreat tucked up high in the mountains. Here there are isolated waterfalls, cool rock pools ideal for swimming, and peaceful hikes in the surrounding hills. This is also a great place to try pony trekking - one of the best ways to enjoy the scenery is atop a sure footed Lesotho pony. We drive through the lowlands of Lesotho and visit Thabo Bosiu or Mt. Moorosi with a local guide (time & weather permitting). This mountain stronghold was the home of Chief Moshoeshoe, the founder of the Basotho nation. We continue through Lesotho's tiny capital Maseru, and re-enter South Africa.

Royal Natal National Park to Johannesburg The Royal Natal National Park on the edge of the Drakensburg Mountains has an impressive natural Amphitheatre of massive rock walls. The Tugela River plunges spectacularly over the edge of the Amphitheatre wall, dropping around 800m through a series of five falls. There are over 130km of walking trails around the park-many of which are easy, half day strolls, through beautiful countryside of grassland dotted with patches of yellowwood forest and proteas set against the stunning backdrop of the Amphitheatre. Heading north we pass through small towns and villages, through Afrikaaner heartland, making our way to South Africa’s largest city, Johannesburg. Built as a result of the gold rush, the city has grown into one of the wealthiest cities in the world. We will arrive on the penultimate evening of the trip and be staying at a laid back backpackers in a suburb of Johannesburg, where you can relax by the pool. The trip finishes the following morning

tourName: Watersports and whale watching holiday, South Africa
generalInfo:
Welcome to Southern Africa!

Embark on a captivating 9-day journey through the scenic wonders and vibrant culture of Cape Town and its picturesque surroundings. Starting with two nights in the dynamic city of Cape Town, you'll experience a seamless blend of urban excitement and breathtaking natural beauty. Enjoy thrilling water activities, including a sunset catamaran cruise with views of Table Mountain and kitesurfing along the famed beaches.

As you venture beyond the city, spend one night in Milnerton, followed by another in Muizenberg, indulging in the rich culinary landscape with dinners at renowned local restaurants and picturesque wineries. An overnight sailing trip offers a serene escape on the waters where the Atlantic and Indian Oceans meet, showcasing the region's stunning marine life and starlit skies.

Continue your exploration with one night in Simonstown, where you'll encounter historic charms and natural splendor, and then two nights in De Kelders, immersing yourself in marine safaris and quaint coastal experiences. Each location offers unique activities and restful evenings in carefully chosen accommodations, ensuring your journey is as relaxing as it is adventurous.

As your trip concludes, reflect on a diverse tapestry of experiences that perfectly blend adrenaline, tranquility, and cultural immersion against the stunning backdrop of Cape Town’s diverse landscapes. This tour promises an unforgettable mix of excitement and serenity, tailored to showcase the best of South Africa’s coastal allure.

On your last day, you'll fly home , filled with unforgettable memories and a newfound appreciation for the adventurous spirit that is Africa !

dayInfo.description: Sunset Sails and Starlit Tales Welcome to your first day in Cape Town, a city steeped in history and bursting with natural beauty. Your journey begins with a seamless airport pick-up by Hannival's Tours, promptly at the time of your arrival. As you leave the bustling airport behind, you'll be whisked away to your accommodation in one of the city's serene neighbourhoods. Parker Cottage, where you'll be staying for the next two nights, isn't just any guest house. Built in 1895 by the influential John Parker, first mayor of Greater Cape Town, this historic building has been lovingly preserved and updated. The decor combines antique elegance with contemporary comforts, creating a warm and welcoming atmosphere. Each of the ten luxurious en-suite rooms boasts unique character, outfitted with modern amenities while respecting the building's historic charm. The cottage operates sustainably, maintaining off-grid systems for water, electricity, and climate control, and holds a Fair Trade Accreditation. After settling into your room, the evening promises a spectacular start with a 1.5-hour sunset catamaran cruise. Departing from the picturesque V&A Waterfront, Luxury Yacht Charters offers a tranquil escape on the waters. The Atlantic Ocean at sunset provides a breathtaking backdrop as you glide past landmarks like Table Mountain and Robben Island, illuminated in the soft evening light. As night falls, we suggest dining at Willoughby & Co. located within the vibrant V&A Waterfront. Known for its fresh seafood and sushi, Willoughby's offers an authentic taste of Cape Town's culinary excellence. The atmosphere here is lively yet unpretentious, making it a favorite among locals and visitors alike. Returning to Parker Cottage for the night, you'll find peace and privacy in your luxury room, a perfect end to an invigorating day in Cape Town. The personal touch of the guest house, coupled with its rich history and commitment to sustainability, makes it an ideal place to unwind and reflect on the day's adventures. Meal Inclusions: None

Seas the Day ... Whales, Seals, and Culinary Feasts ! The second day of your Cape Town adventure begins bright and early, as Hannival's Tours arrives at Parker Cottage to provide transport for the day's excursions. The first stop on your itinerary is an exhilarating Ocean Safari with Ocean Wonder, departing from Granger Bay at 09:00 AM. This two-hour tour offers a chance to see the marine diversity of the Atlantic seaboard up close. From majestic whales and playful dolphins to the myriads of seabird species, this safari is a thrilling way to experience Cape Town's abundant sea life in its natural habitat. Following the ocean safari, lunch awaits at the exquisite Chef's Warehouse @ Tintswalo Atlantic. Nestled at the base of Chapman's Peak, Tintswalo offers not just delectable cuisine but also breathtaking views of the Atlantic Ocean. The restaurant is famed for its sophisticated atmosphere and impeccably crafted dishes, providing a tranquil setting to relax and savour the flavors of local and international gourmet fare. The adventure continues in the afternoon with Seal Snorkelling in Hout Bay from 13:30 to 16:00. This unique experience allows you to swim alongside Cape fur seals in their natural environment. The playful and curious nature of these marine mammals makes for an unforgettable and intimate wildlife encounter, all under the guidance of expert snorkelling guides who ensure a safe and respectful experience in the water. For dinner, we recommend Miller's Thumb, a cozy eatery known for its eclectic decor and warm ambiance. Specializing in seafood and various international dishes, Miller's Thumb makes each meal a memorable event with its vibrant flavors and friendly service. It's the perfect spot to wind down after a day full of aquatic adventures. Your second night concludes back at Parker Cottage. Reflect on the day’s rich experiences as you settle in for another peaceful night's sleep. Meal Inclusions: Breakfast Only

Wind-Washed Wonders and Culinary Delights Your morning begins at 9:00 AM with Hannival's Tours picking you up from Bliss Boutique and transporting you to the beach where your adventure with Open Ocean Africa kicks off. Here, you’ll engage in a kitesurfing session designed for beginners. The experienced instructors will guide you through the basics of harnessing the wind and waves, offering a thrilling introduction to this dynamic sport. Cape Town's renowned winds and beautiful coastline provide the perfect playground for this exhilarating activity. After your kitesurfing experience, you'll be ready to refuel with a delightful lunch at Happy Folks from 12:00 PM to 2:00 PM. This restaurant is known for its vibrant atmosphere and health-focused, delicious meals that cater to all palates. Enjoy a leisurely meal in a cheerful setting where the food is as wholesome as the smiles around you. At 2:00 PM, the adventure continues with a beginner windsurfing lesson from Windsurfing Cape Town, led by the experienced Katja. This session offers you a chance to glide across the water, learning the techniques required to manoeuvre and balance on the windsurf board. Set against the stunning backdrop of Cape Town's beaches, it's an ideal way to enjoy the natural beauty of the area while picking up a new skill. As the sun begins to set, prepare for an exquisite dining experience at Jéan Restaurant, located at the Klein Roosboom Boutique Winery. Dinner at Jéan is not just a meal, but an event. Nestled in a picturesque setting with cozy dining nooks inside converted concrete wine tanks, the restaurant serves dishes that are a testament to culinary artistry, made from locally sourced ingredients and paired with top-tier wines produced on-site. Your day concludes with a stay at Bliss Boutique Hotel in Milnerton. This one-night stay in a Superior Deluxe Queen room offers serene luxury and stunning views of the ocean and Table Mountain. The hotel combines contemporary elegance with personalized service, ensuring a restful night after a day full of adventure and exploration. Meal Inclusions: Breakfast Only

Feathers, Peaks, and Beach Breaks Your day begins at 9:00 AM with Hannival's Tours providing transport to your first destination, SANCCOB (South African Foundation for the Conservation of Coastal Birds). This visit offers a rare glimpse into the vital work of seabird rehabilitation. At SANCOB, you'll see firsthand how rescued penguins and other seabirds are cared for and prepared for release back into the wild—a deeply inspiring start to your day. Following your inspiring visit to SANCOB, you'll embark on a Peninsula Tour from 10:30 AM to 3:00 PM. This tour takes you through some of the Cape's most picturesque landscapes, including the breathtaking Chapman's Peak Drive, the charming harbour of Hout Bay, the lush vineyards of Constantia, and the dramatic cliffs of Cape Point Nature Reserve. Each stop offers stunning views and a chance to experience the diverse beauty of the Cape Peninsula. Lunch will be at The Commons in Muizenberg, a popular spot known for its vibrant atmosphere and delicious, sustainably sourced cuisine. Enjoy a relaxed meal here, which is a perfect midday pause during your tour. At 3:30 PM, get ready to hit the waves with a 90-minute surfing lesson at Surfshack Surf School. This session includes board and wetsuit hire, and whether you're a beginner or just brushing up on your skills, the experienced instructors at Surf Shack will ensure you have a great time riding the waves of Muizenberg's famous surf spots. Dinner is planned at Bang K, a culinary gem known for its bold flavors and unique dishes. Enjoy an evening filled with delightful tastes in a chic and casual setting, perfect for reflecting on the day's adventures. The day concludes with an overnight stay in a Cube Apartment at Bella eV in Muizenberg. This self-catering accommodation offers modern amenities and sleek design, providing a comfortable and stylish base as you unwind from a busy day of exploration and excitement. Meal Inclusions: Self-Catering

Maritime Bliss and the Cape's Two Oceans The fifth day of your holiday offers a relaxed morning in the coastal town of Muizenberg, known for its laid-back vibes and colourful beachfront. Enjoy a leisurely start to your day, exploring the local cafés or simply soaking up the serene beach atmosphere. Transport for the day is provided by Hannival's Tours, ready to take you to your next culinary stop. Lunch is at Bertha's in Simonstown, a charming seaside restaurant known for its fresh seafood and picturesque views of the harbour. It’s a perfect spot to enjoy the local flavors and watch the bustling activity of this naval town. Post-lunch, embark on a memorable journey with Cape Town Yacht Charters for an overnight sailing trip around the stunning Cape Peninsula. This excursion offers a unique opportunity to see the meeting point of the Atlantic and Indian Oceans from the deck of a yacht, possibly spotting marine life such as seals, dolphins, and even whales. Dinner will be served on board, allowing you to enjoy a delightful meal under the open sky. Experience the tranquil beauty of the ocean at dusk, dining to the gentle lapping of waves and a backdrop of the sun setting over the sea. Your night will be spent aboard the yacht, where you can retire to the gentle sway of the sea, under a blanket of stars. This overnight sailing trip not only promises breathtaking views and serene moments but also an intimate experience of the ocean’s nighttime splendour. Meal Inclusions: Breakfast & Dinner

Underwater Whispers and Seaside Dining Begin Day 6 with another exhilarating adventure, this time delving into the depths of the ocean. After being picked up by Hannival's Tours, your day starts with a Freediving Shore Trip led by Shamier Moegmat of Apnea Addicts. Experience the serene world beneath the waves as you learn the basics of freediving in the clear, cool waters off Cape Town's coast. This session offers a blend of challenge and tranquillity, providing a unique opportunity to connect with marine life and explore underwater landscapes without the encumbrance of scuba gear. Following your underwater exploration, unwind with dinner at Harbour House in Kalk Bay. Situated right on the rocks, this restaurant offers spectacular ocean views and is renowned for its fresh seafood and elegant atmosphere. Enjoy the sound of waves crashing against the shore as you dine, making for a perfect end to an adventurous day. Conclude your day at Moonglow Guesthouse in Simonstown, where you will stay in a Queen room with a balcony. Moonglow is ideally positioned on the mountainside, providing panoramic views of False Bay. The room's balcony is the perfect spot to relax and take in the scenic vista, reflecting on the day's underwater journey and anticipating the adventures yet to come. Meal Inclusions: Breakfast Only

Whales, Waves, and Wonders of the Wild Your seventh day in Cape Town starts early, with transport provided by Hannival's Tours whisking you away to a Big 5 Marine Safari adventure with Marine Dynamics. From 7:00 AM to noon, immerse yourself in a spectacular wildlife expedition that offers close encounters with the marine life of the South African coast. This part of the ocean is teeming with biodiversity, including sharks, seals, and, depending on the season, the majestic Southern Right Whale. The knowledgeable guides from Marine Dynamics will enrich your experience with insights into the lives of these incredible creatures. After your morning on the water, enjoy a well-deserved lunch at Rosemary’s Country Kitchen in Gansbaai. This charming eatery is known for its cozy ambiance and delicious, hearty meals prepared with local ingredients, providing a warm welcome after your ocean adventure. Post-lunch, we suggest continuing your exploration of the natural beauty of the area with a hike to the historic KlipGat Caves. Located in the Walker Bay Nature Reserve, these caves are not only a site of significant archaeological interest but also offer stunning views of the coastline and the ocean beyond. For dinner, head to Kuslangs, a local favorite that boasts a relaxed seaside setting and a menu that highlights the best of coastal cuisine. Enjoy the casual, friendly atmosphere as you dine with the sound of the waves providing a soothing backdrop. End your day at Whalesong Lodge in De Kelders, where you will stay overnight in a room that combines comfort with breathtaking views. Positioned on the cliffs above Walker Bay, Whalesong Lodge is the perfect spot to watch the sunset and perhaps catch a glimpse of whales in the distance, offering a peaceful and picturesque end to a day filled with natural encounters. Meal Inclusions: Breakfast Only

Paddles, Pinot, and Picturesque Paths Kickstart your eighth day with an invigorating sea kayaking session with Walker Bay Adventures from 8:00 to 10:00 AM. Paddle through the calm waters of Walker Bay, where you might spot dolphins, seals, and during whale season, the awe-inspiring Southern Right Whales. This guided adventure not only offers a unique vantage point to view marine life but also allows you to experience the tranquility of the ocean up close. Following your morning on the water, refuel with lunch at The Wine Glass in Hermanus. This sophisticated restaurant is celebrated for its extensive selection of local wines paired perfectly with gourmet dishes that showcase the region's best produce and seafood. The relaxed yet refined atmosphere makes it an ideal spot for a leisurely lunch. The afternoon is yours to explore Hermanus on foot. This charming coastal town is famous for its natural beauty and friendly locals. Stroll through the streets, visit local shops and art galleries, or relax by the seaside, soaking in the laid-back vibe of the town. For dinner, head to the Blue Goose, a quaint restaurant known for its warm ambiance and excellent cuisine. Specializing in fresh seafood and traditional South African dishes, the Blue Goose offers a delightful culinary experience in a cozy setting. Conclude your day back at Whalesong Lodge, where another night in comfort awaits. Spend the evening relaxing on your balcony or by the fireside, enjoying the serene environment and the stunning ocean views that make Whalesong Lodge a perfect retreat. Meal Inclusions: Breakfast Only

Homeward Bound On your final day, you'll begin with a comfortable transfer back to Cape Town from De Kelders, provided by Hannival's Tours. This drive offers you a last chance to reflect on the unforgettable experiences and scenic beauty of your South African adventure as you journey back to the city. Upon arrival in Cape Town, you will proceed to the airport where you will board your flight home. This departure marks not just the end of your trip but the beginning of carrying these memories and stories with you, as you return from the vibrant landscapes of Cape Town to the familiar comforts of home. Safe travels!

tourName: West Coast nature tour, South Africa
generalInfo:
Welcome nature lovers, solace seekers, and those simply looking to recharge, to a peaceful corner of the Cape, down the West Coast.

Only two hours' drive from Cape Town, the West Coast is known for its glistening windswept beaches, heritage fishing villages, rich geographical diversity and its beautiful succulents and spring wildflowers. During August and September, the West Coast National Park bursts into a vast array of colour as Spring brings with it a landscape of flowering fynbos and veld.

Your 4-night, 5-day tour will give you another perspective of Cape Town. The West coast is a hidden gem filled with delightful little towns like Saldanha, Paternoster, St. Helena Bay, Hopefield, Darling and Langebaan to name a few... The white sand beaches surrounding the clear waters of the Langebaan Lagoon are one of the main attractions of Langebaan. The mild climate and protected waters of the lagoon make Langebaan popular for sailing, kayaking, kitesurfing and fishing, and the town offers numerous holiday facilities for water sport enthusiasts.

The tour is design to give you an insight and appreciation of the Indigenous people of South Africa and experience the peaceful nature and warm hospitality of the West Coast. Visitors flock to the West Coast National Park to be treated to magnificent displays by Southern Right whales passing the sea shores during August and September. It's magnificent beaches, tranquil and beautiful landscapes transport visitors to another world. Community events include the church bazaar and the annual Langebaan Mussel Festival, which takes place on the first weekend of October. There is plenty to do in this part of the world!

dayInfo.description: Upon arrival at Cape Town International Airport, you collect your rental and drive to your first accommodation on the West Coast. (1 hour, 30 minutes) Enjoy the hospitality of the staff who are mostly from the Indigenous people of the South Africa. Learn about their culture and heritage through one of their immersive tours. A hearty meal infused with indigenous plants and produce will give you a deeper understanding of this 100,000-year-old culture. Here you may find yourself staying up all night, chatting under starlight, making friends who last a lifetime.

After breakfast, you can explore the surroundings. There are running, hiking and biking trails to suit all tastes or gentler trails around the werf. Explore the West Coast national park and surroundings which will dazzle you with its unspoilt, scenic landscape. Lunch will be in the town of Langebaan, known for its active water sports vibe.

After breakfast, you continue your journey into Paternoster, one of the oldest fishing villages on the West Coast of South Africa. It is known for its white-washed fishermen's cottages. Arrive at the first sustainable guest house situated along the pristine beach.

After a delightful breakfast prepared by the beautiful local women of the guest house, there are some activities to enjoy, handpicked by accommodation. You can go on a E-Bike tour along the beach, walk to the nature reserve, enjoy an early morning guided sea kayaking tour or even horse riding on the beach. If you want to pamper your body and soul, a qualified mobile therapist gives the absolute best massages and beauty treatments in your room or on your own terrace. Yoga sessions by swimming pool or on the beach, the possibilities are endless.
Check out from the quiet and serene and head back to the most beautiful city in the world! From here you can extend your stay, we will be happy to assist you.

tourName: Western Cape wildlife holiday in South Africa
generalInfo:
Explore the terrestrial and marine ecosystems north, south and east of Cape Town and come face to face with whales, dolphins, albatross, black rhinos, baboons and even the once extinct quagga on our Western Cape Safari.

Introduction:

We are specialists in tailoring wildlife watching all over the world and we have a great range of wildlife tours in Southern Africa which combine various different wildlife events. In order to develop our unrivalled range of combined wildlife watching holidays, our guides and colleagues around the world have spent years searching out the world’s best wildlife watching locations as well as visiting some seldom visited areas. This dedication has led us to create this wonderful tour that explores the incredible and diverse ecosystems of the Western Cape of South Africa. Anyone interested in the natural world will no doubt know that there are very few better destinations than South Africa. This tour focuses around the beautiful city of Cape Town and you will pretty much be in the shadow of Table Mountain throughout most of the tour. Using Cape Town as a base for the first few days we will head out to sea and explore the marine ecosystems around False Bay and the Cape of Good Hope. Here southern right whales, cape fur seals, African penguins, dusky dolphins, great white sharks, dozens of marine bird species and possibly humpback whales and orcas reside. But we do not end there as you will also explore the Table Mountain National Park where the unique fynbos floral kingdom in home to many endemic birds, baboons, ostriches and antelopes such as eland. We also head inland to Karoo National Park where the once extinct quagga is being bred back to life and coupled with black rhinos, aardvarks and other arid zone creatures are our main targets. But just as we started at sea we end at sea by heading to Gaansbai where whale watching is once again on the agenda. All of our tours are guided by our own professional zoologist (- zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us) so you are sure to be in the best hands possible for the best sightings. Our escort for this tour has experience working on a in South Africa as well as working on various studies marine life around the world. We also have a great network of local guides in South Africa who have developed a great range of wildlife watching locations where the rarest species are commonly seen. Also to try and make sure that we will see as many of the rarer and elusive animals when in Karoo National Park we will spend many hours during the early morning and late afternoon on jeep safaris and also after dark each night we will head out with high powered spotlights and start the search for nocturnal species. One of the reasons why our wildlife watching holidays are unique is that our background (as a company) is from a scientific and zoological standpoint and so have a great network of colleagues and contacts all over the world who are the people on the front line in search of the best new locations for wildlife watching. All of these reasons and many more make us experts in arranging safaris and are able to tailor a safari to any location to try to find your targeted species. All you have to do is to get in touch with your budget and your group size and where you would like to go to try and find rare and elusive species.

Price Includes:

Everything mentioned in the itinerary is included. Including three meals per day (breakfast, lunch and dinner). There will be bottled water (approx 1ltr) available for each guest each day. We have our own private air conditioned vehicles with an excellent driver for all transfers and a 4x4 vehicle for all safari activities. Where possible we use two brilliant guides; first a professional zoologist (- zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us) will escort you on all your excursions and also very knowledgeable English speaking local guides who have decades of experience working and guiding through Southern Africa. Your zoologist (- zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us) escort is an expert in mammal biology and behaviour and will be able to help you identify the different species as well as interpret you what behaviours you are seeing. The local guides have spent years searching out the best wildlife watching locations and have an unrivalled knowledge of where some of the most elusive African animals are. As well as having years of experience in bringing people out to see sharks, whales, lions, elephants and other wildlife safely. We also include all vehicle safaris, guided walks, spotlighting drives, seal island cruises, pelagic trips, whale watching excursions, park entrance fees and sightseeing entrance fees. We include more time spent in the field searching for wildlife per day than any other tour operator around; only if you request to have a rest day will we not arrange a safari into the African bush or trip out to sea for whales or dolphins. A comprehensive species list (which states the relative chances of seeing animals based on past tours) is included in the pre-departure pack. There is also a reference book library available for your use throughout the trip as well as some documentaries on the wildlife that you are likely to see which are available to watch throughout the tour.

Seasons:

The southern Hemisphere winter is best, July - October. This tour is best in the southern Hemisphere winter into the southern spring. This is when the weather is at its most comfortable for us to visit and the seas around the Cape of Good of Hope are calm enough to allow pelagic birding trips as well as whale watching excursions too.

Why Choose this Tour:

• All of our wildlife watching holidays are guided by a local naturalist guides, drivers and also scientists or researchers where possible, this not only gives you numerous sets of trained eyes to find the animals but also gives you the chance to understand the behaviours and habits of the wildlife your watching.
• Our zoologist (where available - if you wish to have a zoologist please contact us and we can check availability - not all tours include a zoologist) that escorts tours (where available) has a great wealth of knowledge.
• We can offer you spotlighting trips of the Karoo National Park so that you can search for the rarer species and other nocturnal wildlife when they are more active.
• We can also bring thermal imaging and night vision equipment as well as hydrophones (on request) to also aid in finding the nocturnal mammals after dark and listen in on the underwater conversations of whales and dolphins.
• We use camera traps (where available) which will increase the chances of getting close up pictures and movies of rare animals and other rare nocturnal wildlife.
• Climb the stunning and iconic Table Mountain for exceptional views of Cape Town.
• All the above reasons give this tour of Southern Africa’s Western Cape a great success rate of seeing the best wildlife around here. We have an unrivalled network of experts and guides throughout Southern Africa so that we can try and find and observe animals such as the Big Five, many sharks, whales, dolphins and hundreds of other species throughout Southern Africa. Whether it is the South Africa, Namibia, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Mozambique or Zambia or any of the other many wildlife watching locations you want to visit we can arrange it. Please inform us if you wish to receive more information about any of these locations and booking a safari.
• Unlike many tour operators we are willing to run this tour for a single person (on request).

Locations:

This tour travels starts and ends in Cape Town whilst exploring the marine ecosystems around the Cape of Good Hope and False Bay as well as Gaansbai and also heading inland to the arid national park of Karoo.

Fitness Level:

The vast majority of wildlife watching is all done from the 4x4 safari vehicle or from whale watching boats so any fitness level can participate.

Equipment:

When you book onto the tour we will send you a comprehensive pre-departure pack which will include a full packing list of recommended equipment; the equipment list will vary from tour to tour and from location to location so it is best to contact us or wait until you receive the pre-departure pack after booking.

Minimum Age: 16 Years Old

dayInfo.description: Cape Town – Arrival – On arrival at the Cape Town International airport, you will be met by your local guide. If your flight arrives in the morning we should have time for some sightseeing after you have been transferred to our accommodation in Simonstown. Simonstown is a beautiful little harbour town situated on the south side of Cape Town and is nestled between False Bay and Cape Point National Park. On the drive from the airport there is a chance of spotting black wildebeest, Cape mountain zebra, eland and grey rhebok as the motorway flanks the national park boundaries. Once we have checked in and grabbed some lunch (depending on the time) we will head out to Simonstown’s number one attraction. Boulders Beach National Park. This is one of the smallest national parks in all of Africa but it is home to a huge population of African penguins. They nest here and the beaches and pathways get you really close to the birds as they fearlessly waddle right up to you and seem more interested in you than you are in them! In addition to the penguins there are plenty of rock hyraxes or dassies here. They are the closest living relatives to elephants but you have to look hard to see why as they look more like guinea-pigs. We can stay here as long as you like and afterwards we can either go back to the accommodation so you can rest or drive around the bay and take in some of the sites, including a view of Table Mountain in the distance. Our evening meal will be back at the accommodation. (Lunch and or Dinner included (depending on the time of arrival)).

Karoo National Park – Travelling & Wildlife Watching – This morning after breakfast we will leave Cape Town and drive inland to a very special national park (6.5 hours). We will stop for lunch along the way. Karoo National Park is isolated park and is mostly semi-desert but boasting more tortoise species than any other park in South Africa and recently playing home to the re-birth of the quagga, Karoo really is more than just semi-desert. In fact we have a good chance of finding black rhino, cape buffalo, red hartebeest, black wildebeest, kudu and both the Cape Mountain zebra and the quagga-like-Burchells zebra. The quagga project has bred the Burchells zebra to havce quagga like characteristics and as the quagga was only a subspecies of the Burchells zebra it is not as farfetched as it may sound to bring the quagga back from extinction; and if we are lucky enough to see one you will agree they look pretty convincing. On arrival we will check into our accommodation, level - cottages / chalets (national park main camp) and get ready for a night drive with a national park warden. The spotlighting drives are the best and usually only way to see some really remarkable animals like aardvarks, aardwolfs, bat-eadred foxes, African crested porcupines, striped polecats and African wild cats. We will have our evening meal in the camp restaurant. (Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included).

Gansbaai – Travelling & Whale Watching – After breakfast we will leave the Karoo National Park and drive back towards the coast. Our destination is Gansbaai (8 hours), a place that is more famous for great white sharks than probably anywhere else in the world, but there are also very large populations of southern right whales and humpback whales here as well as cape fur seals which will be our main focuses. We will have stopped off along the way for some lunch and by the time we arrive we will check into our accommodation. The rest of the day will be at your leisure. Our evening meal will be at our accommodation. (Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included).

Gansbaai ¬– Marine Wildlife Watching – This morning we will breakfast before departing on a whale watching boat around the bay. The bay is home to many thousand cape fur seals and each winter migrating southern right whales and occasional humpback whales. There are also resident populations of bottlenose dolphins, long-beaked common dolphins and dusky dolphins as well as many species of marine birds. It is also worth keeping an eye out for the bay’s other resident during winter, the many great white sharks that come here to feed on seal pups in the winter. They are not easy to spot but can be seen whilst looking for whales and dolphins if you keep yours eyes peeled. When we return you will have the afternoon at leisure, relax or explore Gansbaai. Our evening meal will be at our accommodation. (Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included).

Cape Town – Marine Wildlife Watching & Travelling – This morning after breakfast we will again take a visit out to Dyer Island again to look for southern right whales and other marine wildlife. On our return to shore we will have lunch and then leave Gansbaai to Cape Town (2 hours). We will arrive at our accommodation, in Simonstown once again and the rest of the day is for you to relax on your last night in South Africa. Our evening meal will be at our accommodation. (Breakfast, Lunch and Dinner).
Home – Departure – This morning you will be transferred to the airport in Cape Town in time to catch the return flight to home. (Breakfast only).

tourName: Wheelchair accessible South Africa self drive holiday
placesVisited: Cape Town, Stay on the slopes of Table Mountain, Franschhoek Valley, Explore the Winelands region, Opportunity for whale watching trips in Hermanus, Knysna, Garden Route, Pletternberg Bay, Big Five Safari for two days, Fully wheelchair accessible tour
generalInfo:
The wonders of South Africa are too many to name, but you’ll have the freedom to take in many of them with this wheelchair accessible self-drive holiday. Your accommodation and car hire are taken care of, leaving you free to make your way between destinations choosing your own route and pace.

Spend a day exploring the key attractions of Cape Town, perhaps taking the cable car to the summit of iconic Table Mountain, or learning the history of Robben Island, where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned for 18 years.

Drive to a sedate corner of the beautiful Franschhoek Valley in South Africa’s Winelands region, where you’ll have ample opportunity to tempt your palate on both wine and local, organic food.

Next you’ll make for the coast, and Hermanus with its high cliffs, regarded as one of the best locations on the planet for whale watching – perhaps a good place to book a boat trip, or simply see what you can spy from the clifftops.

Continuing through Knysna, famed for its seafood and especially oysters, drive a section of the glorious Garden Route as you make your way to a safari park. Here you’ll spend a couple of days taking guided game drives in hope of seeing the Big Five – and of course this being South Africa, you have an excellent chance.

As this is a wheelchair accessible holiday, your operator will discuss your requirements before departure to ensure your needs are met, such as by booking ground floor rooms, and suggesting suitable restaurants and other attractions.

dayInfo.description: Depart from UK. Overnight flight from London to Cape Town.

Cape Town. Arrive in Cape Town and pick up your hire vehicle. Drive to your accommodation for 3 nights stay on a bed and breakfast basis. Your accommodation is in an exclusive and luxurious boutique hotel on the slopes of Table Mountain. The city, its harbour and the surrounding mountains are all visible from your private terrace.

Explore Cape Town. Ride the cable car to the top of Table Mountain, take the ferry to Robben Island, soak up the atmosphere at the V&A Waterfront, enroll in a cookery course in Cape Malay cuisine, take a township tour or drive the Peninsula circuit.

Franschhoek Valley. Drive the relatively short distance to Franschhoek in the Winelands for a 2 night stay at a beautiful wine estate. Set in a peaceful corner of the Franschhoek Valley, the emphasis is on organic, home-made food and local wines. The area has 3 main towns, each a bit different, but all worth exploring. A day out visiting local vineyards is a must.

Hermanus. Head to Hermanus for a 2 night stay at a luxury retreat perched high on the Hermanus cliffs. This beautifully appointed boutique hotel offers uninterrupted views and diverse activities, the very finest in international cuisine and luxury accommodation. Hermanus has the status of being the best land-based whale watching destination in the world. Southern Right whales visit Walker Bay from June to December and can be viewed from aboard a boat, an airplane or from the shoreline.

Knysna. Drive towards the Garden Route. You are headed for Knysna for a 2 night stay at a beautiful guesthouse in a room with a sea view. Knysna is the place to be for savouring seafood fresh from the sea. Knysna oysters in particular are popular. The harbour is a great place to relax and watch the sunset from one of the many waterside restaurants and bars.

Plettenberg Bay. Further on from Knysna, Plettenberg Bay has stunning beaches and is a resort town with a relaxed atmosphere. Here, boat trips to see dolphins and whales operate in season, and sea kayaking, horse riding, sailing trips and surfing are on offer. Just two minutes walk from Central Beach, your six suite designer boutique beach lodge offers an unbeatable location, magnificent views, tranquil contemporary beach décor and a roof terrace with Jacuzzi.

Big 5 safari. Move on to your private game reserve for a 2 night stay in a luxury twin tent on a full board basis, including local brand drinks and two safari activities daily. It is the ultimate luxury Big 5 African safari adventure and conservation effort coupled with responsible tourism. You will be assigned a personal game ranger to a maximum group of 6, who will design your daily program with you.
Return home. Drive to Port Elizabeth Airport, where you drop off your hire car and fly to Cape Town, arriving in time for your return flight to London.

tourName: Wildlife Photography Internship, South Africa
generalInfo:
Discover the thrill of photographing Africa’s iconic wildlife while building your skills under the guidance of professional photographers. This internship offers a rare chance to combine adventure, conservation, and creative growth in one unforgettable experience.

Each day brings new opportunities: sunrise game drives, golden-hour shoots, and evenings spent refining your images with expert feedback. You’ll learn how to anticipate animal behavior, compose striking shots, and master the use of natural light. From elephants and lions to vibrant birdlife, every encounter helps you expand your portfolio and deepen your connection to the wild.

Beyond photography, you’ll gain insight into conservation challenges and the role of storytelling in protecting ecosystems. Living in comfortable shared lodges within the reserve, you’ll enjoy hearty meals, camaraderie with fellow interns, and workshops that sharpen both technical and creative skills.

Highlights include:
- Guided game drives and bush walks with trackers
- Mentorship from professional wildlife photographers
- Workshops on editing, storytelling, and portfolio building
- Opportunities to support conservation through visual documentation

Whether you’re preparing for a career, enriching your studies, or pursuing a passion, this program offers a transformative journey. Leave with stronger skills, unforgettable memories, and a portfolio that reflects the beauty and urgency of Africa’s wilderness

tourName: Wine and art holiday, South Africa
generalInfo:
South Africa is synonymous for fine dining and great wines…to say the least. The Cape Winelands draws you in every sense of the word…it possesses the lavish landscape, the majestic mountains and produces the fruit of all its labour. With a wine culture that stretches back for centuries, this tour will introduce you to the best wines in the region.

In the last decade, there has been a significant development in South Africa’s contemporary art scene, particularly in the capital city. The arts sector has flourished rapidly, especially after the inauguration of the Zeitz Museum of Contemporary Art Africa in 2017. This vibrant mother city has been a major epicentre for African art, Indigenous art, and artists. The expression of its rich and complex political, cultural history is evident in the work of some of the most exciting emerging artists of the region. With an exponential growth of art galleries as well as public and private institutions, matched with rising demand for African art around the globe, there is an endless amount of art to explore in the bustling, picturesque city of Cape Town.

The trip will see us blend wine with music, art, cheese, chocolates, and even biltong. You can even attempt the ancient art of Sabrage with the assistance of your ambassador. This unique tour will combine these two exceptional sectors and invite the novice art lover to the wine enthusiast. Something for everyone. And if you enjoy all of this, it is made with you in mind!

dayInfo.description: Your shuttle awaits you at Cape Town International Airport. Your accommodation over the next few days is a charming country wine estate with an incredible story of transformation.The beautiful country estate lies in the small town of Wellington. Once you are settled in, you can stroll in the gardens or relax at the pool. Later, you will enjoy a delicious dinner at the on-site restaurant. Wellington is situated at the foot of the Groenberg on the banks and forms the centre of the Cape Winelands with its picturesque environment and numerous wineries.The perfect climate in Wellington, supports the production of some exceptional "big red" varieties such as Shiraz, Pinotage, and Cabernet Sauvignon. Chenin Blanc and Chardonnay are the main white varieties and great examples of these are also in abundance. We start our wine & art tour here...

After breakfast, we visit the cellar in the Oude Molen, Stellenbosch for a wine making experience. Led by an inspirational woman who will passionately share the art of winemaking. After the demonstration, we started our wine-tasting tour in the historic town. Stellenbosch is the second oldest town in South Africa and is known for its natural beauty and oak-lined avenues, Cape Dutch architecture, history, and culture. The town lies in a fertile valley surrounded by vineyards, orchards, and mountains. It is an academic and farming community and one of the best-preserved towns in South Africa. On your way back, you will stop at a wine farm with a beautiful sculpture garden and enjoy a wine & olive tasting.

Franschhoek is a small village nestled at the bottom of a fertile valley in the heart of the Cape Winelands, surrounded by rolling green hills, strawberry farms, and endless rows of grapevines. Today, we start with wine and poetry before getting onto the popular wine tram that stops at several wine farms for wine tastings. You will stop at one of the farms which take you to the next level, by making, bottling, corking, and labeling their own red or white blend in a 1.5l magnum bottle. You can even attempt the ancient art of Sabrage with the assistance of a wine ambassador. For lunch, you will indulge in a traditional South African meal set on a boutique wine farm.

After tasting and drinking for days, today you can explore the countryside on your own. Our guide will give some tips on what to do and where to go, or you might just want to stay in. The country estate is quiet and walks on the farm will be refreshing.

After breakfast, we head to the city exploring Cape Town's vibrant art scenes. We will stroll through art galleries and visit the Zeitz Museum of Contemporary Art. You will have time to walk around the V&A Waterfront before we head back to the winelands. We stop at a wonderful wine farm that showcases South Africa's Indigenous artists.
Our wine tour comes to an end, but there is always chance for one more! That is your surprise and our secret!

tourName: 10-Day South Africa Tour: Kapama, Winelands and Cape Town
placesVisited: Kapama Private Game Reserve, Stellenbosch, Cape Town
generalInfo: Discover the majesty of South Africa and its wilderness on this tailormade 10-day tour, taking you from the emerald expanse of Kapama Private Game Reserve to the spectacular golden beaches of Cape Town. Along the way, you will capture the Big Five wandering through the bushveld and uncover significant South African heritage during tours of its age-old wine scene as well as iconic landmarks dotting the city beneath Table Mountain.

dayInfo.title: Kapama Private Game Reserve - Touch down in the Rainbow Nation
dayInfo.description: Your South African safari begins as soon as your airplane swoops over the golden plateaus and rolling forested hills stretching across the rainbow nation. You will touch down in the Greater Kruger Area, meet your private transfer, and make your way to the beautiful bush of the Kapama Private Game Reserve. Dense emerald jungles teeming with roaring animals and lush vegetation will circle your stunning suite in a hideaway lodge equipped with lovely amenities. You may spend your afternoon enjoying the soundtracks of nature, from the whistling birds to the chirping crickets, while tucking into decadent South African cuisine.

dayInfo.title: Kapama Private Game Reserve - Behind the Scenes with the Big Five
dayInfo.description: Kapama’s enormous stretch of forest and wilderness is home to a remarkable collection of indigenous creatures you will soon discover alongside a spirited ranger during morning and afternoon safari drives. Your adventures will lead you through the shamrock-colored canopy to lookout points sharing unbridled scenes of the bushveld and to watering holes where hippos and buffaloes escape the heat of the African sun. Searching for the Big Five, you may stumble upon prides of lions wandering across the landscape, witness elephants plodding across open pastures, and see rhinos grazing the sprouting grass.

dayInfo.title: Kapama Private Game Reserve - Walking with the Wilderness
dayInfo.description: While game drives are a great way to see as much of the wilderness as possible, South Africa’s untamed beauty is only truly uncovered once you step off the vehicles and capture the scenes up close. Today, you may hop off the 4x4 vehicles and stroll through the bush, encountering curious little creatures and catching wafts of the blossoming flowers as you wander Kapama. This intimate nature exploration will allow you to stop and unwind with the wildlife, picking up footprint trails and tracking them with your ranger to daringly discover what lives beyond the borders of our cities.

dayInfo.title: Stellenbosch - Welcome to the Western Cape
dayInfo.description: Today, you will leave the emerald expanse of the Greater Kruger Area and transfer to the Western Cape, where you will touch down at Cape Town International Airport and head to the rolling green hills of Stellenbosch. Home to the Western Cape’s premier wine estates, Stellenbosch is a regal food and wine retreat nestled in one of South Africa’s most illustrious settings. You will arrive at your delightful accommodation tucked away between the hilltops and may spend the afternoon relishing the amenities offered at your resort.

dayInfo.title: Stellenbosch - Sipping Wines under the African Sun
dayInfo.description: Enjoying your stay at one of Stellenbosch’s coveted wineries, you will have access to South Africa’s beloved wines on your doorstep. Today, you will join a sommelier after breakfast and enter the estate’s wine cellar. Hundreds of barrels of fermenting wines will lay across shelves hidden within the cellar, waiting to mature and be bottled for the pleasure of wine lovers around the world. You will settle in at a white-linen draped table in the manicured garden and sip on sumptuous wines paired with delicious tapas and cheeses as the birds sing from the circling trees.

dayInfo.title: Stellenbosch - Wondrous Wine Taste Tour
dayInfo.description: While Stellenbosch is home to an incredible collection of decadent vintages, a short drive away lies the rest of the Western Cape’s phenomenal wines in the Cape Winelands. Today, you will join your guide and make way for the exemplary estates dotting the flourishing hills stretching between Stellenbosch and Cape Town. Along the way, you will stop at an assortment of esteemed estates to discern the nuances in flavors presented by the various bottles produced from each destination's distinct vineyards. Views of the cascading vineyards and the echoes of singing birds will backdrop your gorgeous taste tour of Cape Town.

dayInfo.title: Cape Town - The Dynamism of Cape Town City
dayInfo.description: On the morning of your seventh day, you will transfer from your accommodation in Stellenbosch to a gorgeous hotel stationed in the heart of Cape Town city. Boasting access to the city’s impressive cultural landmarks and iconic heritage sites, you will be encouraged to see the wondrous sights and take in the city’s dynamic energy from the minute you arrive. Whether you wish to stroll through the manicured lawns of Company’s Gardens or enjoy an engaging history lesson at Cape Town’s lavish museums and art galleries, you will be consistently blown away by the presentations of South African culture.

dayInfo.title: Cape Town - Captivating Scenes along the Breathtaking Cape Coast
dayInfo.description: Beyond cultural immersion within the city limits, exciting opportunities to connect with South African heritage spread out from its borders and around its peninsula. Today, you will join a knowledgeable guide and set a course for the roads winding around the Cape Peninsula. The long drive will reveal the region’s immaculate coastal beauty stretching from the city’s beaches to Simon’s Town and Cape Point. While meandering along the rugged coastline, you will stop at fishing villages to feed hungry seals, peruse antique museums that have been around for decades, and cruise along the famous Chapman’s Peak drive.

dayInfo.title: Cape Town - Discover What Brings the People of South Africa Together
dayInfo.description: There are several significant highlights to still check off your South African travel list before you depart, so you may spend your final full day exploring all that this magnificent cosmopolitan has to offer. From ascending via cable car to the summit of the soaring Table Mountain to crossing the sea en route to Nelson Mandela’s former prison cell on Robben Island, there is culture and heritage to uncover wherever you go in Cape Town. Your day touring Cape Town’s beloved sites and monuments will reveal the tumultuous history that led to a country now united.

dayInfo.title: Cape Town - Memories of Marvelous South Africa
dayInfo.description: All good things must come to an end and, although it will be sad to be leaving the stunning scenes of South Africa, you will return home with a myriad of marvelous memories made along the way. As the sunshine breaks over the horizon and life sets into motion once more, you will tuck into a delicious breakfast spread while gazing up at the towering precipice of Table Mountain. After breakfast, you will be collected by your private transfer and whisked off to the airport, where you will catch your plane headed home.

tourName: 11-Day Highlights of South Africa: City to Beach
placesVisited: Cape Town, Sabi Sands Game Reserve, Johannesburg, iSimangaliso Wetland Park
generalInfo: South Africa’s dreamy coastal destinations and dazzling multi-cultural cityscapes, from the rugged Blue Flag beach-hugged coastline of the Cape Peninsula to the vibrant suburb of Sandton in Johannesburg, are yours to adore on this 11-day exploration from the Western Cape to KwaZulu-Natal. Whether it’s snorkeling in the crystal clear waters of the Indian Ocean or witnessing the wilderness of Sabi Sands, South Africa is calling for adventure.

dayInfo.title: Cape Town - South Africa’s Crown Jewel
